Ted could not be swayed, however … I suppose all we can do ( now that Ted has left us ) is keep an ear to the ground to hear of any transgressions past the deal he agreed to — and simply hope he will find his precious souls in those who have earned such a … shitty ending.
ior. We bicker as usual, of course, but there's a shift in our rapport. Meanwhile, Mirabelle's concern extends to Varus, who's been wrestling with Ted's infernal dealings.
With Anur in the lead, we begin our climb up the icy cliffs. I spot a grey-furred tabaxi who seems to be everywhere, raising both curiosity and suspicion.
In a clearing, this tabaxi – Luck by name – greets us with puzzling mutterings and swirling pupils. He's concerned about his shadow and the disfavour of one Ambassador Ushan.
Pixies promptly arrive, and Garnet, mounted on a beetle, appears on my shoulder, demanding Luck's teeth or a special gift. I will admit: I was viscerally uncomfortable, and think I spent the majority of the ensuing time either sweating or shivering.
Gifts of narration and song were offered, and Anur even surprised us all with her skill on the lyre. With these gifts presented, the pixies departed — but I fear I'll have repercussions to deal with in return for my lack of preparation. I was told, in a whisper I wish to forget as fast as I can, to not "trip on my words next time", before they vanished. My anxiety swelled to the point where I openly sought the comfort of a held hand, wary beyond any measure I've ever felt before. Not even traversing the Sevenfold Mazework put me this far on edge.
Either way, with both Varus and Mirabelle kind enough to humour my request for someone to hold my ( admittedly sweaty, at this point ) hands, and Luck accompanying us, we climbed higher into the mountains, and settled in a cave for the night. Jade green hues shade our resting place, and in the far distance, a sunset hints beyond the jagged mountain tops. I can only hope I'll still be here come the next morning, rather than suspended upside-down by a tree, or comically disfigured by the displeased pixies.
If I was certain beyond any doubt that they can't read Terran, and that they can't access my diary, I would ‘compliment’ them and their ‘crafty’ ways. Note to self: never improvise a poem again. Also, next time think of something more dramatic. Good grief.

character-logs/aerendyl-19.html.title: Aerendyl 19
character-logs/aerendyl-19.html.description:
Day 25-26 of Bloomweave, year 515 T.A.?
In the presumed safety of our cave, we exchanged names, real and fake, amidst the tension lingering from prior events with the pixies. I felt uneasy, my nerves frazzled, a sensation that muted my voice more than I'd like to admit.
Jorinn, whom we'd come to know as Luck of the Draw, admitted once more he had lost count of his time in this place. Having been a merchant back in Sylvari, exile to the Feywilds seemed to have stretched long for him. Yet our conversation took turns; he even bested me at arm wrestling — which cost me five gold in the friendly wager.
Our dialogue ventured deeper — Jorinn's devotion to the Raven Queen lay in the medium of memories, a practice carrying more weight with each recounted past. Ambassador Ushan's mention brought speculation on the years that had folded since Jorinn had last walked among the Sylvari (300 at worst, apparently?!).
Arguably of more interest to myself, though, Jorinn is headed for the Silver Maple. He even confirmed his task as such must be to deal with the source of the Pale Blight, alongside various others sent out to what may well be certain death.
On first watch with Jorinn, the comfort of the comparatively temperate cold and a secure cave eased the watchful hours. The sky's nocturnal ballet showcased Lucanthus in its viridescence, a calming contrast to the previous night's capricious display. The occasional sound from outside drew our attention—a branch snapping, a tree falling—but nothing came of it.
Jorinn's tale of being ensnared by the pixies in their displeasure painted the forest as an unforgiving loop of traps and deceit. His warning of a potential curse prompted a check of my rations — indeed, I was down to one. In an act of providence, Jorinn went out to forage, and returned with an unexpected feast of bounty.
Dawn brought chaos as we clashed with the elusive dwarf that vanished into the pack during our encounter with the poachers. Her fate was bloodily sealed at the end of the skirmish. The issue of the pack persisted, though; Anur's desire to delve into it weighed against Mirabelle's insistence on understanding the hunter's narrative.
Anur's intent on entering the pack led to a collective decision; ensuring its security demanded creativity. The choice to pursue an animal guardian fell to Jorinn, who returned with an almiraj named Phlip, while I closed the entrance to the cave after patching up Anur (likewise alongside Jorinn).
We were prepared to enter whatever lay in the pack stealthily. Anur, in her guise as a fallen enemy, led us in — upon which all of us, save for Anur, were caged upon entering. Her quest for tokens to authorise our release sent her away, leaving us encased and uncertain.
The prison's bars were eerily reminiscent of the cold iron found in the Bitter Steppes at home, including their anti-magical properties. All we could do as such was wait in lieu of risking a botched attempt at escaping and triggering more alarms ( or worse ), until Anur returned with the means to unshackle us: tokens bearing Asmodeus' seal, striking deeper questions about our actual location.
My best guess to this point is that we're in a demi-plane of some sort. I suspected the Abyss for a moment, but the sigil anchoring the portal in place simply didn't seem to suggest it. All the same time, knowing the symbol on this seal has everything to do with Asmodeus, still raises questions. This place is called “Dain's Prison” – and by virtue of our last talk with Ted, I recall Glasya, Asmodeus’ daughter, rules the prison plane of the hells (Malbolge). What if this “Dain's Prison” is somehow connected to it? Related to it? It is the only way in which the symbols on these tokens make any sense to me.
Ah, I digress. We ventured further after a moment, down the stairs, and were greeted by braziers that seemed to conceal more prisons. Lining the walls, tables held both scholarly scrolls and unsettling dissection instruments. Amidst a cold emanating glow, Jorinn's and my attempt to obtain a shard from a peculiar crystal teetered between curiosity and caution—the material's fragility and volatility reminiscent of volatile cold iron.
The others already ventured farther down the stairs. Time to follow suit, rather than risk blowing up this place for the sake of a sliver of that cold, glowing crystal …

character-logs/aerendyl-20.html.title: Aerendyl 20
character-logs/aerendyl-20.html.description:
Session 20 Day 26 of Bloomweave, Year 515 T.A.?
in which aeren decides to use everyone’s actual names again both because he himself gets confused + to confuse any strangers that might come across his diary, gods forbid
Luck and I gathered a hefty share of food from the larder before we joined the others, upon which I was tasked with creating an opening around the bars of some type of cell (these fools didn't account for a genasi!), granting Runa access to a figure huddled within — battered and weak, but our fighter-friend's approach radiated concern and tenderness. For a few moments there, I couldn't help but ponder the relationship between the two, and I was made to think of those whom I went my letters to before we set out for the Feywild.
The place prevented us from aiding the stranger, later introduced as Tanis, with magic, unfortunately, so we resolved to vacate the area post-haste to tend to her ailments properly. The goblin child that lingered in the corner, Jinx, agreed to join us in our retreat.
As we prepared to leave, our conversation turned to Spite, a tiefling mage apparently all to eager to live up to his name, had stoked in the tower. His 'floor' loomed with ill repute. The stranger tranger led us to a chamber that held a personal artifact – a cord with a pendant – that she swiftly reclaimed.
We swiftly left this demi-plane then and, once settled, Luck provided a potion for Tanis in a finely crafted goblet — special in some way, as he insisted it be returned to him after use. News of being in the Feywild startled her, but she swiftly mustered resolve, speaking of acquaintances in the Summer Court we might seek out. Tanis recounted her past — a captain who once stood sentinel against corruption at the Ironwood Citadel.
Tanis's tale unfolded as she wrapped herself in Runa's bedroll, managing her own care while Mirri divulged her pursuit of Vestan Tlanbourn in time — a name Tanis recognized with a scowl.
The discourse darkened further when hellfire weaponry and their devastating potential were brought forth by Mirri, who apparently found some in the unnamed demi-plane we just left (I still suspect it is somehow tied to Malbolge …). The weapons' power to sunder reality itself brought forth an inevitable discussion as to what next to do with the pack. We debated its fate, ultimately deciding to contain its threat within Corvaux's own enchanted bag for the time being. Despite the risk, Corvaux, took the decisive step, leaving us startled, but unscathed.
With preparations complete, we departed from our temporary cave haven, but not without another encounter with the whimsical pixies. To earn our passage, I recounted the story of my transformation, Da'yin Kuya's aid in helping me become who I was meant to be, and at what personal cost. Thankfully, the pixies seemed to accept my tale — at least I received no warning to essentially 'do better' next time.
Our passage paid by stories and teeth, we left the mountains with minds and hearts set upon the realm of Autumn. Our journey continues, the weight of our task and the newfound companionship of Tanis urging us forwards.

character-logs/aerendyl-22.html.title: Aerendyl 22
character-logs/aerendyl-22.html.description:
Day 26 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
A new dawn found me stirring from a deep slumber within the cosy confines of the Froggit About It inn. As I rubbed the sleep from my eyes, I made my way to join the others aboard the Crimson Gaze, a ship unlike any I'd seen before. There, after being treated to a drink by Mirri, amidst the raucous revelry of pit fight celebrants I was engulfed by waves of wyrmroot smoke that bridged my senses with the ethereal plane due to no fault of my own.
My memory is a bit fuzzy beyond this point beyond the recollection of the incredible colours I witnessed that night, but I do distinctly recall searching for a vantage beyond the ordinary, and so I climbed to the crow's nest where one Wisp presided a card deck and fortune-telling stones. I inquired the stones about the Stonecutter, and Wisp translated their symbols of loss, zeal, and wealth to me — a cryptic foretelling that left me pondering what shared fate might await both the Stonecutter and myself.
Once I was on deck below, I observed Luck after a while, the pipe at his lips casting shadowy swirls, punctuated by red motes igniting my curiosity. Paired with the raven-like shadow I saw about him earlier, one might paint me curious as to what might hide behind that otherwise jovial and pleasure-forward self-presentation of his.
The evening waned and weariness took hold, in any case, drawing us back to the inn, sinking into a sleep filled with homesickness — a yearning for the familiar places traversed and those left behind in cross-planer my journey.
The light of morning revealed an unforeseen ailment, as Corvaux displayed their scaled arm, an unnerving gift from the abyss. Corvaux called it Phage, and suggested we all get examined by the healer at the Heart Tree. There, we encountered Kelsea, who confirmed Corvaux's singular plight among us, and spoke to us of the Silver Maple's condition, Scarlet City's past with the Blight (and suggested there may be more recently contaminated individuals in town) — which, now that I'm writing about it, feels like ... we should not leave without investigating, right? What if we come back and the town is in disarray due to an outbreak?!
Impromptu crisis aside: we were pointed to the Drunken Cantor for the tools to shield ourselves against the corruption should we choose to venture into Silver Maple (though we are first going to Autumn, as far as I'm aware).
A murmur about the taste of decaying honey upon contamination with the drew a grim blanket over all of us. Scarlet City knew the Pale Blight's touch — a crisis mirrored in Corvaux's Yewdon, sealed but festering for centuries. Our paths reconciled in a sense; most of us seem willing to assist him in Silver Maple once the time to head there comes, though I admit to finding myself somewhat relieved we are first going after Mirri's Tlanbourn – as far as I'm aware, at least. I sense a distinct reluctance among some of us to follow a near stranger into what may turn into certain death.
Not to say that facing this Tlanbourn will be any different, but at least I know Mirri a touch better — well enough to throw myself into a fight for the sake of exacting justice by knocking him down a peg or two. I feel like we've bonded just enough to achieve that much, but, then again, I have been called a gullible cretin in the past ...
Either way, we're getting exactly nowhere without doing some shopping for the bare necessities, if we can call it that. Luck pursued a Moorbounder kitten while a frost puppy, Grout, suddenly claimed a share of our lives as well — Mirri and I now as co-parents to this frosty, bounding ball of joy.

character-logs/aerendyl-24.html.title: Aerendyl 24
character-logs/aerendyl-24.html.description:
[Session 24] Day 28 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
Runa left overnight, and that took us all by surprise – though I get the impression I’m the only one that needs a moment to actually process it. She left behind only a note telling us not to follow and a poem, which seemed entirely unlike her, but, on the other hand, it just goes to show how little I knew about her.
In a way, it makes sense. She seemed annoyed by us more often than not, or at the very least aloof. I know for one I’m the one that gets attached far too easily — give me twenty-four hours at someone’s side, and if there’s no instant ill fit to speak of, I’ll wind up all too invested. She seemed the polar opposite. I would’ve liked to see what lay beyond that reserved nature of hers, but … well, that’ll just be another of those what-ifs, I suppose.
I didn’t have much time to process once I got up in the morning. It unveiled the first sunrise I've witnessed in far too many days. Seeing it at last, I felt a wave of something akin to relief.
Setting forth after spending some time occupied by Grout, Golden Oak was the direction we were to go in, though the road there was said to be home to a wailing witch, and was described as a necropolis of sorts. With Luck leading our path, an effort to choose the most direct route was constantly diverted by the wild's will. Maybe I’ll take charge next time …
Either way, at length we reached a temple of theRaven Queen by a cliff within a colourful, marshy part of the forest. I was taken by the beauty of the surroundings — trees adorned with colours that seemed painted by light. It was [Mirri]]'s keen eye that caught the the sound of a lone figure playing the lute, her chords striking an unnerving resonance.
Approaching the bard, later revealed to be named Deidre, she confessed to being trapped here and requested our help. It wasn’t too difficult to surmise, then, that this was the wailing witch we were warned of. Either way, she sketched a dire situation in vague details — jailers donning animal masks, leaving behind a fog over her memory.
Interestingly, she also read Corvaux's inked skin, identifying the markings as anchors of her roguish skills of sorts. She also seemed to grow anxious at Grout's presence. Afraid of canines ..?
Our resolve to help notwithstanding, we first entered a nearby temple dedicated to the Raven Queen, a place of memory and exchange revealed itself. While some offerings were made to the Raven Queen by those dedicated to her, I joined Mirri outside.
I gave her the moss I’d picked up some days ago ( writing this down so I don't wind up wondering where I left it! ), so she could exchange it for a Rowan stick on the ground. She explained it possessed magical protective qualities: it keeps internal magic in, and external magic out through a magical absorption sort of property. She intends to use the stick to work on something that might give her a bit of an edge — in the fight with Tlanbourn to come, I suppose?
As we set off towards our new objective ( the mansion Deidre is apparently tied to ), Corvaux soon sensed an ominous surveillance and before long, we found ourselves hidden atop a ridge, ready to thwart danger that loomed from the shadows.
The confrontation was sudden — a shadowy assailant attacking Corvaux. It began as a hidden strike but quickly escalated into open combat, with the entire group defending against the encroaching threat.

character-logs/aerendyl-25.html.title: Aerendyl 25
character-logs/aerendyl-25.html.description:
Day 28 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
After the battle, Corvaux and Deidre explored the fallen tree where it all began. The tree bristled with an unseen force, and though my companions were out of sight, Corvaux soon returned with filigree weapons from the entangled bodies within its roots. Luck surmised they were likely the possessions of guards. Meanwhile, Deidre had run off and scurried back; the distance from the manor seemed to wear on her. She implored us to assist her in breaking the curse anchoring her to the mansion soon.
On the journey back, my gaze fell upon the younger trees. I recognized where old trees had once stood, their absence marking decades passed. We reached the mansion built upon ancient roots, deciding to pause for understanding before entering the dark spellwork that bound Deidre.
We scoured the first floor to no avail and then ascended. The balcony greeted us with paint stains, investigated and tasted by Corvaux. An intricate door bore sinister red runes, while a stone sigil whisked me back in time to a memory with Bell, a pair of cultists, and summoning circles.
The broken sigil captured my attention; I dedicated an hour to unravel its secrets, imagining its origins and destinations. The others, meanwhile, ventured into the sigil-guarded room as a haunting and beautiful tone enveloped me—the song of a star, a melody Wisp had alluded to, unheard of in Autumn. Time to put that sending stone to work once I have a moment.
I followed inside at length, found myself … welcomed by a wink from Deidre, and then … I don't know just what came over me, but I followed her as she ventured into another room. I won't get into unnecessarily embarrassing details, but it turned out I followed her right to the threshold of her bedroom. Scratched out self-deprecation here!!!
We parted ways and I trekked upstairs. entering there a chamber enshrouded in webs, where Luck identified a simple cat amidst the gossamer threads. Now, I'm not afraid of spiders, but I'd like to be able to see them and not be caught off-guard by them. So, do I trust these webs? No, not quite.
Anyway, Mirri stood fixated on a sizable egg—a dragon's egg she was keen to pilfer for future profit. I wish she wouldn't, especially after hearing Luck break … whatever he broke in an adjacent room. Whether Deidre was bound here by force or not, this is her home, right? Why rob her when we promised her our help? I find it all a troubling … lack of respect. Perhaps I ought to speak up before the day is over. Who knows what mischief a short trance will allow Mirri to get up to well before I've awoken after a night's rest!
The nearby books narrated tales of dragons, and before us was a statue, a jade wyrmling at rest. As we flipped through the pages, we uncovered a gruesome story of 'The Furthest Branch,' slaughterers and traffickers of dragon parts traded as vile trophies—a revelation that left a foul taste in my mouth.

character-logs/aerendyl-26.html.title: Aerendyl 26
character-logs/aerendyl-26.html.description:
Day 28/29 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
In the quiet hours before we sought out our bedrolls, I reached out to Wisp with the sending stone, discussing the peculiar sound haunting my thoughts. Wisp confirmed it was related to the star she could hear, and, since the Crimson Gaze is departing in two days, asked if I could trace the sound to its source before then—two days! How am I to even do that? It lingers as an unsettling challenge even now—cross-planar communication holds a sliver of uncertainty, after all, and I don’t expect the Crimson Gaze to hang around in the Feywild after departing.
The next morning, I got to wondering whether something's wrong with Corvaux—not in the offensive sense, but she's been sleeping; dreaming, even, instead of going into a trance. I wonder to what end she's doing that, but I haven't the heart to pry.
Instead, I asked Mirri not to indulge further in theft while she pored through a massive tome, urging some respect toward Deidre's home. Yet as words faltered, I found Mirri unmoved—and, somewhat comically, the egg she pilfered missing from her possession. I got the impression she blamed me for it …
Oh, well. Maybe Grout or Ralph got their sticky little paws on it. In any case, Corvaux and I headed off to prepare tea for the group atop glowing coals, which is when we stumbled upon symbols amongst the wood—a death's-head moth and a rough diamond, the latter which was especially familiar to me as a symbol of Dounuma's (or Dumathoin, if you will). A conversation with Deidre about such ominous icons is due at some point, but we had more pressing matters to resolve, first.
Together, Corvaux and I sought Deidre, where I clumsily offered tea, only to witness it discarded with nonchalance—an embarrassing testament to our different tastes, I suppose. We apologised for Mirri's pilfering. In retrospect, I'm relieved she wasn't there to hear it. I fear she'd have struck us both upside the head with a well-aimed Eldritch Blast in retaliation for speaking on her behalf.
Before long, our ensemble convened to devise a plan. The vault beneath the manor most likely contained the heart of the curse. Deidre recounted a symbol to beware of—a symbol eerily familiar the several I've found in the Stonecutter's journal.
decided to reveal the contents of the journal to the group—not just one person; not just to Corvaux as I did before, but everyone. The depth of the Stonecutter's work startled both Mirri and me with its potency, detailing entities known for pilfering souls, evoking the name of the dreaded Orcus, and a record narrating an inquiry into the lineage and purpose of missing souls. The symbols somehow seemed to depict anchors of such souls, in a sense?
Mirri stressed the power described in just these few pages, warning that it must never fall into Tlanbourn's hands. In fact, she would sooner set the journal and myself on fire than let that happen. She would have to; my resolve to hang onto these wretched pages and follow them to my destination is stronger now than ever before. I'll not give this up willingly.
Based on these findings, though, I theorized the circular symbols Deidre sketched out might just be what's anchoring her here—her soul, specifically. Depending on the exact state of the symbol, we might need to destroy it, or dismantle it by tampering with the Weave that powers it. It'll be tricky nonetheless, I expect.
So we traversed to the basement, Ralph and Grout left above to avoid harm. We found the entry sealed, but with Corvaux's touch, the stone slid away, revealing the steps into depths gilded as solid gold. Below, statues and a white bowl before a lit effigy of Lord Aurelius (or Eristalon, as we've come to know the name) beckoned for an offering. Deidre's wooden wolf idol granted us passage.
In the next chamber, a grand harp stood amid silence, and we discovered a sigil requiring a key—the solution lay within a treasury that awoke armoured assailants as Corvaux and Mirri crossed its threshold. After a scuffle, we claimed the gold and gems inside, aquamarine crystals particularly catching my eye—a near sacred piece of my homeland.
Mirri's critique of my fascination with the gems sparked bitterness; I felt the chasm my earlier request might have given way to, widen. Nonetheless, we affirmed the spoils were not Deidre's to start with (so I assume they belonged to this Eristalon), and divided them fairly amongst all of us. In hindsight, I wonder what might become of us if he ever finds out what we took from his treasury …
With this chamber practically emptied, a secret chamber revealed itself, one that turned our stomachs with decay and one that encompassed something other than golden, shiny wealth—organs, daggers, and the lingering questions that now we must still answer.

character-logs/aerendyl-27.html.title: Aerendyl 27
character-logs/aerendyl-27.html.description:
Day 29 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
Today's explorations in the manor's depths proved both wondrous and unsettling. As I examined the crystals and amber adorning the central table, Deidre donned a thorny crown, much to Mirri's chagrin. Corvaux sensed hidden magic within it, piquing our curiosity. Another crown similarly held promise of some magic potency—something that would turn "if looks could kill" into reality, I believe?
I admittedly found myself somewhat distracted during the explanation, for amidst the gems on the centre table was a piece of amber, flawlessly cut, with a small acorn suspended inside, glowing with a golden aura. Corvaux handed it to me, and I was transported back to my journey to Rakāuvi, to a tale an old man spun about Silvanus.
Deep in a forest far to the south-west of Rakāuvi, lies a tree where Silvanus slumbers. When he stirs, roused by anger, the tree drops golden acorns imbued with the power to cheat death itself. A seed of resurrection, forever tied to his resting place. We agreed to safeguard this treasure, should dire need arise—even if death, indeed, is a natural part of life. I won't have us lightly use such an item as such.
My attention then turned to a tome sealed within a blue dome—the Dendritic Grimorium. Its pages no doubt held forbidden secrets of controlling plants and forging unnatural connections, echoing Thaddeus' interest in the murals about bringing stone to life; turning it sentient. When I queried Mirri about her own research, her curt dismissal left me bristling. Her apparent bitterness hung like a shroud I could not pierce.
As we paused near the coffins, an unseen force intervened. From my pack tumbled a glass eye, its gaze fixed unerringly upon me. Panic gripped my heart—it seems a hag named Sabina, spurned by Deidre, is now watching my every step. This must be those scratched out pixies’ doing. Oh, I do so treasure the variety of life—but I will be the first to admit there is no love lost between myself and them. Either way, I hastily buried the eye deep in my belongings, where it must have spent the past few days, praying it would bring no further misfortune to my companions until we have a moment to address the matter properly.
We had a task to complete first, after all. We returned to the locked door in the first chamber, which after some trial and error, Corvaux managed to unlock, permitting us to pass farther below ground. Here, we encountered a sprawling sigil scrawled in myriad tongues—Abyssal, Druidic, Sylvan. Mirri understood the grand majority of what was written there; I needed only pitch in to help her decipher the Druidic, which seemed … strangely off-beat.
Her sudden demand for privacy between herself and Deidre caught me off guard. Reluctantly, I followed Corvaux and Luck, my heart heavy with worry for Deidre and frustration at my own impotence.
Relief washed over me when they both returned, seemingly unharmed, with Deidre proclaiming her newfound freedom. But a new mission called—the remains of Kai, her ghostly friend, awaited recovery.
A small jaunt later, we found ourselves in what felt like catacombs of sorts—the walls set with bones, skeletons suspended from chains, and coffins smattered about an off-shoot of the main chamber. Urgency seized Corvaux as she plunged into the well at the centre before long … with the Stonecutter's journal in her pack. Without hesitation, I went after her alongside Mirri, Deidre, and Luck.
As we sank deeper, the sound Wisp foretold grew ever louder in my mind, its call unmistakable…

character-logs/aerendyl-28.html.title: Aerendyl 28
character-logs/aerendyl-28.html.description:
Day 29 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
The Well's depths greeted us with warmth and the gentle rush of distant waters, a stark contrast to the bones carpeting its bed. A small canoe bobbed beyond the entangled roots, while sated redcap mushrooms dotted the surroundings, their thirst for blood temporarily quenched by Corvaux's apparent intervention before we even got down here.
Deidre and I illuminated our path with a torch, and soon, she uncovered Kai's skeletal remains. As we all mused over Elven funerary rites, Deidre and Corvaux delicately retrieved the bones from the watery graves. With the skull in hand, Kai faded from view, exhaustion claiming his ethereal form.
Amidst the depths, the star's melody swelled, a symphony of wind and draconic phrases intertwined with an unfamiliar tongue. With some concentration, the others could hear it, too, to varying extents. Its theme was centred around “creation”, “celebration”, “awakening” … Somehow, perhaps because of this slow recognition, the sound became less eerie, and more so alien.
As we ventured towards the boat, a peculiar figure emerged from the shadows—a myconid, its mushroom cap crowning layered robes. Chip, this new acquaintance of ours from theBlight Commune, extended an invitation to their domain, but first, some of us – mainly Luck and I, with Deidre choosing to accompany us – needed to return to the surface to gather Grout, Ralph and possessions.
During our ascent – unfortunately at the cost of Corvaux plunging into the water once the Flight spell was cast on me … –, I offered to carry Luck and Deidre. Luck was easy enough to carry, and Deidre helped carry her weight by … well, clinging to me like a monkey of sorts. All very cute, and I admit I quite appreciated the embrace, though that appreciation turned to me being flustered as her fingers found my hair. It was a gentle, rather unfamiliar touch that set my cheeks ablaze. Her whispered praise only deepened the hue, and I found myself grateful for the fact she was holding onto my back and not my front, obscuring my flustered reaction.
‘Listen’ carefully, whoever might read this (shame on you for snooping!): it is not like I don't know how to accept affections, or even solicit them. She simply caught me unprepared. Anyway …
Reunited with Grout, Ralph, and our belongings, we descended once more below ground, the star's song resuming its ethereal refrain. But before we could decipher its meaning, Mirri called us to attention, her demeanour tense.
She spoke of Vestan Tlanbourn, the Elven sorcerer she'd hunted across planes for over half a century. His vile ambitions to tear asunder the fabric of reality and beckon forth the Abyss had left a trail of destruction, the recent carnage on a Sylvari farm a grim testament to his cruelty. Only young Nettie had survived, shielded by a nearby shrine's grace.
Well, Nettie, and Malachai—or the Scribe, as the cultists apparently called him, and the Stonecutter in most of my entries so far. It was apparently he who had painted the walls with bloody scripture, opening the rift into what must have been the 108th layer of hell—or an attempt at it. I don't actually know if that rift led to its intended destination, and at that point, I didn't bother to ask.
This moment felt pivotal, for we were ( and are ) close to the Fallen Halls where we hope to find Vestan. Now that the explicit ties between Vestan and Malachai were made clear, or the purpose the latter served to the former, I felt it was no longer appropriate for me to hold back the truth—especially not as the others seemed to grow progressively more suspicious of the trouble I had hiding my reactions to every mention of Malachai's name.
As the truth regarding who he was – or is – to me spilled forth ( my father ), Mirri's face drained of color. Fear, and something more inscrutable, contorted her features. She reveals she fears leading us to our doom—and perhaps me in particular, a genasi who always strived to attain Malachai's level of skill with stone and crystal. With Malachai having escaped Vestan with Mirri's and Runa's help, what if I’m considered the next best option?
Or worse: what if my mother is? Malachai did say he had no time to spare; that he had to protect his family. Unless he has other children I am unaware of … I must return home, and fast—the second this mess here has been resolved. I won't trust his word for it if he tells my mother is safe—or even if he tells me the opposite. I must see for myself … assuming not too much time has passed there, in comparison to the Feywild.
Now all the cards are on the table, at least as far as I can tell, we resolved to spend the last hours of the day seeking out this start – we're so close; I can feel it! – and gather our strength before confronting Tlanbourn. But as the hag's eye lingered in my pack, a reminder of unseen threats, I now can't help but wonder what twisted paths lie ahead, and what price we'll need to pay to see this journey through.

character-logs/aerendyl-29.html.title: Aerendyl 29
character-logs/aerendyl-29.html.description:
Day 29 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
Today was a day of gathering, both in supplies and revelations. We descended upon Master Silo's shop, procuring an assortment of potions and herbs. I bagged myself two pipes alongside a few doses of Dream Grass, as a treat: one made of quartz, resembling a dragon, and another made of wood, featuring two twined branches of sorts. Mirri even treated me to my dose of Druid's Dram.
But that was only my personal highlight of the day. Our towering host, Silo … something something IV, proved to be a kindred spirit in his proclivity for herbal relaxation, but more important than that was his stock beyond the remedies for our collective anxiety. Mirri sought a charm-repelling potion to no avail, so I bartered for vials of holy water, a necessity for a protective spell. Mirri's silver tongue and Deidre's unexpectedly pup-like eyes even helped secure a small discount—31 gold pieces per mixture, instead of 35. Truly, I thought Deidre's gaze could rival Grout's in terms of its capacity to endear …
But it was Luck's earlier find that turned out to be the most surprising find of all, really. A demon, trapped within a bottle, waiting to latch onto the nearest portal and tear open a rift to the Abyss. The 108th layer, if my intuition serves me right. A pattern I've grown uncomfortably familiar with. I'd like not to gain more hands-on experience with it than necessary, so I do hope he keeps that bottle firmly sealed.
Master Silo spoke of a necrotic frozen lake in need of cleansing, a task for another day. For now, we retired to the Slumbering Blossom, where Mirri opened up about Vestan Tlanbourn, the mage who's haunted her for 54 years—a span equal to my entire life. She painted a picture of a charming, manipulative caster, his true visage obscured by time and dark deeds.
But it was her own tale that struck me to the core. Vestan's ritual, the black ichor, the abyssal runes drawn onto ( or into ) her skin—a pact made manifest.
Mirri's pain was palpable as she recounted how Vestan took her brother's life, a mere 29 years of age. The weight of her family's scorn, the burden of survival—it all crashed over me like a tidal wave.
Perhaps the most chilling revelation to me, personally: her belief that my father, Malachai, might be one of Mystra's Children, a mage of unparalleled power born in the wake of the Spellplague's end.
Could he really have been chosen by Mystra herself? Literally?
No matter the answer to that question, a promise was due and so I made it—perhaps naive in my optimism, but fuelled by the unshakable faith in our group's strength and its burgeoning cohesion. We will see this through: Mirri's tale will not end in tragedy. Not on my watch.
As the night wore on, Mirri, Deidre and I indulged in some Dream Grass to upend the tension for a while, followed by a dose of Druid's Dram for Mirri and I not long after. Luck, meanwhile, succumbed to a potion-induced vision, a flying castle hurtling towards him … I think? Really, at that point, I was rather out of it, too. Mirri and I, lost in the haze of the tincture of sorts, heard the fungus sing, its joyous melody drowning out the star's ethereal refrain for the first time.
The giddiness that came with it all is slowly dissipating as I write this. Now to see if it is enough to permit a talk with Da'yin tonight …

character-logs/aerendyl-30.html.title: Aerendyl 30
character-logs/aerendyl-30.html.description:
Day 30 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
Oh, the dating is entirely off now, I suppose. I now have reason to believe the days pass about four times faster back on Rakāuvi and back at home. Or maybe it's three – I need to gather my thoughts about it whenever next I have a spare moment, I believe. In any case ...
Last night, as I drifted into the realm between waking and dreaming, I found myself once more in the presence of Da'yin. Her visage was not as I remembered – its geodesic properties having grown dull, grey almost, and her surroundings bare-bones in comparison to the chambers lined with shelves and books, jars, ingredients … Her home, apparently, lies now in ruins, and three of her siblings were lost to the cruelty of corrupt Roshmarian mages. These vile cultists (always the cultists of late …), disciples of the Lord of Lies himself, have a history of enslaving primordials. Da'yin warned me against venturing near Umbrosia and the infamous Rashmore Tower.
If nothing else, this served as a reminder of the centuries of suffering endured by the dao at the hands of mages, demons, and other malevolent entities. To think I once wondered why they're so secretive, isolated … When I offered my aid, Da'yin's response was measured — unless I possessed knowledge of the Roshmarian mages or a pure source of aether ore, my assistance from afar would be limited.
I won't deny still feeling forlorn about the knowledge that I cannot abandon my current quest; not unless expressly bidden to do so, as determined by our agreement. Vestan's threat looms too large, threatening the very fabric of existence. With a heavy heart, I conveyed my predicament to Da'yin, who, in her wisdom, did not begrudge me. Instead, she assured me she has handled worse, that she will rebuild — and even imparted a spell that would allow me to detect sources of pure elemental power, a tool to aid in locating imprisoned genies and, perhaps one day, guide me home through elemental vortices.
Before our communion drew to a close, I shared the events that had transpired since our last encounter. I spoke of Thaddeus' fateful deal, the coming and going of companions, and the looming shadow of Vestan Tlanbourn. But it was the star I'm pursuing that captivated Da'yin — a beacon of pure Primordial energy, a cosmic lynchpin. She spoke of legends, of the "Forge of Apotheosis” some of these stars were captured to fuel … This legend is unknown to me, but something tells me I'll learn the truth of it soon enough.
Naturally, I couldn't leave without mentioning the hag's eye, described by some Fey, apparently, as a ‘fell curse’. Da'yin warned me said curse would only grow in power with time, and advised encasing it in lead for now, or even feeding it to some insatiable creature for now, cautioning against confronting the hag directly. I'm not entirely sure I'll find a creature voracious enough to solve this problem for me, so I must look to alternatives: to convince the hag she holds no sway over me (fat chance, says I), or redirect her gaze elsewhere … A plan hatched then and there: what if I can redirect the hag's malice towards Vestan himself?
Of course, the conversation inevitably turned to my parents, to the revelation of my father's entanglement with Vestan's machinations. Fear gripped me—what if Vestan's cultists sought vengeance against him, now that he'd been free? Was he even free, still? Was my mother? Da'yin, in her compassion, offered to have another see if my mother's safe and deliver a message on my behalf; a warning, more like.
Once I awoke, the world seemed to shift. Mirri, her hands wreathed in inky darkness, climbed through the window, a gelatinous familiar from the Abyss in tow. There was hardly any time to ponder this development—a shadow, cold and strange, lunged at Mirri amidst her ritual to identify a demon-possessed bottle.
The battle was brief but intense, the shadow speaking in Abyssal upon its defeat. Mirri, visibly shaken, revealed it was an old friend, promising to explain when her composure returned. The ritual resumed, unveiling the bottle as road to Orcus' domain, the 333rd layer of the Abyss. So, not the 108th as I suspected, but I suppose that would have been too great a coincidence, wouldn't it?
As we discussed how to dispose of this vile artefact, a few ideas took root. The hatred between devils and demons was legendary—perhaps a devil could destroy what we could not. Or, I reasoned as one of several not particularly drawn to the idea of bargaining with a devil (I'll not follow Thaddeus’ example there), I could seek out another portal to the Abyss and cast the bottle into its depths.
The hag's eye remained a pressing concern, too. We explored options—encasing it in lead or feeding it to a Xorn or other ravenous creature to buy time. I revealed my interest in slipping it to Vestan himself as a way to trick the hag into surrendering her hold over me.
Mirri's revelation about the hag's red hair – per Deidre's description, assuming this even is the same hag she's acquainted with! – sparked determination: we would inflict this curse upon Vestan if given the chance. Apparently, redheads are his type …
Luck, too, faces a curse of his own — why would he keep clear of curses after just having escaped one the pixies subjected him to? This time, the curse is centred around an axe he took from the chamber with artefacts under Deidre's mansion, jealous and needy, identified by Mirri's magic. He and I at least share a goal: to be rid of the items that seek to make our lives miserable!
Gods, we have much to take care of in the coming days …

character-logs/aerendyl-31.html.title: Aerendyl 31
character-logs/aerendyl-31.html.description:
Day 30 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
Our journey took us first to Herbs 'n Legends, where Silo works. He regaled us with a tale of an elderly woman purchasing bags of blood for a supposed "blood stew." While Deidre and Corvaux assured me of the dish's potential deliciousness, I wondered just who this apparently humanoid lady might be – I was somehow under the impression we were the only humanoids in the settlement for now. Silly me, I suppose.
Setting out with Silo, we ventured towards the necrotic lake we'd pledged to help him with. The landscape shifted between barren stretches and lush growths, a dichotomy that left me pondering the nature of the Underfey. It's not like what I've seen in the Earth Plane, nor in any subterranean dwellings I've visited on Rakāuvi. But both places stretch on seemingly endlessly, and I've but seen a few corners of each so far.
I was taken out of my idle reminiscing as we approached our destination, for a biting cold seeped into the air, our breaths crystallizing before us.
The lake, a frozen expanse, glowed with an eerie light beneath the ice. A colossal oak tree towered above to our left, its heights seemingly infinite. Corvaux, ever the intrepid investigator, scaled the tree, almost disappearing from view. They reported a shifting presence under the ice, an elk skull adorned with vines and golden motes on one of the nearby rocks, and a polished stone of sorts hidden among dried ferns on another.
Deidre, levitating towards the lake's heart, found herself sapped of strength by the mysterious light. It became clear that this place was once a shrine, now tainted by an unknown force. Amidst this revelation, I noticed the star's song, my constant companion, had grown muffled — a sign, perhaps, that we were drawing closer to its source.
Our investigation led us to a key forged from Cold Iron, languishing at the lake's depths. Its very presence seemed to poison the surroundings, selectively stifling magic and draining everything that came close to it from life. As I touched the ice, memories of the Bitter Steppes, the drawings I've seen and the tales I've been told of this perilous boundary between Earth and Water in my home plane, flooded back to me. I might have entertained the thought longer, if not for Grout's sudden yelp — not even he, a frost puppy of all creatures, could stand the bitter cold of the ice! And I understand it all too well; withdrawing my own palm from the ice felt akin to freezing one's tongue to an icicle, and then trying to pull it off without leaving its top layer of skin on the ice!
It took a moment, but once I succeeded, Mirri's quick thinking and spell-casting allowed us to retrieve the key, but its handling posed a new dilemma. Cold Iron's properties were not to be trifled with; it's shielding effects towards magic seemed selective to me, and Silo didn't sugarcoat the effects the metal has on Fey creatures — and, I suppose, even those who aren't Fey. Any illness caused by Cold Iron is incurable.
Mirri, through her arcane expertise, identified the key as a gateway to a vault of sorts; a door that is only a door when the key is present. With this knowledge, we split our group — Corvaux, Deidre and Mirri remaining with the key while Silo, Luck, and I returned to the Blight Commune in search of a leaden case to contain both the key and the hag's eye that haunted me. In our search, we opted for a larger case – 600 gold – to contain Luck's cursed axe as well, once he was able to release it from his grasp, at least. Note to self: check in with others about contributing to the costs of the case — yes, even Luck, despite ( or maybe because ) of his abysmal lack of ability to manage his finances effectively. Good grief, I've never seen anything quite like it!
It was in the act of transferring the key to its new container upon our return to the lake, that I was thrust into a vivid, almost tangible vision. My consciousness hurtled through memories not my own, plunging into the vast Jade Sea. I became the jade itself, shattered, collected, and subjected to an agonising cycle of freezing, soaking, drying, hammering and grinding. The pain was unlike any I had ever experienced, and it was only through sheer good fortune and I presume the help of my companions back in the Underfey that I managed to return to myself.
It was an unexpected ordeal, but I took comfort in Silo's kindness shining through as he bestowed upon us unlabelled potions and directions (of sorts) to the Fallen Halls of Eristalon. His attempt to remove the curse of the hag's eye, however, yielded mixed results, due to not fault of his. The eye's gaze upon testing whether removing the curse had worked now fell upon Deidre. A dose of guilt and feeling like a failed court jester was precisely what I needed, of course. So, I suppose the plan to either get it to fixate on Vestan or feed it to a xorn remains.
For now, with the key hidden away, the star's song regained some of its clarity, though its direction remained elusive. Silo, through the use of Augury, provided a glimmer of guidance—the path ahead would lead me closer to my goal.
And so we pressed on, ascending towards the surface once more. We emerged into a glade of breathtaking beauty, soft grasses and lush mosses beneath our feet. Yet, as we approached a grove of towering oaks, an unsettling sight greeted us: flora and fauna alike, transformed into stone ...

character-logs/aerendyl-32.html.title: Aerendyl 32
character-logs/aerendyl-32.html.description:
Day 30 of Bloomweave, 515 T.A.?
As we ventured into the petrified expanse of the forest, my mind raced with possibilities. In the Earth Plane roam creatures capable of transforming their surroundings to mirror their own nature—Earth Elementals of various kinds, primal and barely sapient. I also recalled tales of settlements and caravans that had suffered the wrath of a Dao, left to stand as stone monuments to the folly of crossing such powerful beings. Yet this felt different, like some other force was at work here.
Amidst the grey, we sought a rumoured green presence, the same mystery that had drawn Corvaux's three trainees to this eerie place. Our path soon led us to petrified figures; not the trainees, fortunately, but others, frozen in time for a longer time still. One stood apart, hooded and twisted, a hand raised as if caught in the act of casting. The others, clad in identical armour bearing an oak leaf sigil, lay scattered, seemingly felled by a powerful blast.
Deidre's reaction was visceral—recognition and fear intermingled. These were members of a corrupt order from the old Autumn Court under Eristalon's rule, a group she knew all too well. As Mirri and Corvaux toppled one of the statues in an act of solidarity, I scanned the shadows, wary of unseen observers. The branches above, shattered like stone, hinted at a struggle of some sort. There was no real way of telling how recent it was, though.
Luck's attempt to detect magic yielded nothing, deepening the mystery. How could such widespread petrification occur without a trace of arcane energy? As I pondered this, the star's music, ever-present, began to clarify, almost as if intent on drawing my attention to it. The once garbled phrases took shape, speaking of creation once more, and … cosmic beginnings. Corvaux, too, heard the song—that is, its Celestial vein. We theorised that the star might be linked to the gods themselves, its melody a reflection of their influence, or perhaps the star sings of the creation of the constellation whence it came … Again: I have more questions than answers!
Our exploration then took us to a ruined castle, its collapse clearly postdating the petrification. The deliberate nature of the destruction, with bricks torn from the floor and scratch marks marring the stone, and Luck's particular investigation, suggested the work of a dragon. Deidre's knowledge of the place proceeded to paint a picture of a secluded base, seemingly used by the Autumn Court authorities to hide secrets from the public eye.
The age of the petrification must span a century or more at this point, yet the castle's destruction seemed more recent, with some areas having crumbled mere weeks ago. Not that this knowledge changed much; the recent damage could have been random, rather than the result of a stumbling dragon.
We proceeded farther down the corridor and down the hall, revealing a passage at the building's rear. This led us to a courtyard, where the impossible greeted us. Amidst the stone, living oak trees towered, their leaves rustling in defiance of the petrification. Ivy and moss, vibrant and alive, clung to the central building. Luck's magical detection revealed a chilling truth—the mist that enveloped this oasis was steeped in necromancy. Again. I thought it was mostly Winter that had a penchant for welcoming undead and the like, but I guess I was mistaken.
We prepared to brave the cold with that cold iron key in tow, dark magic permeating an adjacent chamber, but caution tempered our curiosity. As the day waned and Luck's exhaustion deepened, we chose to make camp, to rest and strategise for the challenges ahead.
I have since reached out to Wisp, my thoughts full of the star's ever-louder song. The chase must be nearing its end, but the true nature of my quarry remains elusive. Either way: time for some sleep now, before I must wake and join Mirri on the second watch.

character-logs/aerendyl-33.html.title: Aerendyl 33
character-logs/aerendyl-33.html.description:
Day 1 of Flamecrest, year 515 of T.A.?
During the stillness of night watch, Mirri indulged me in a chance to practice my hand at cartomancy. The Ettin card, a two-headed giant, spoke of her stubborn nature and inner turmoil. When asked if she would attain her heart's desire in the coming days, the answer admittedly eluded me, drowned out by the incessant song of the star I pursued. Instead, I inquired about her wishes—to unravel Vestan's mind, to understand the depths of his cruelty. Our bond deepened as I apologized for overstepping and offered my aid in her future scams, a partnership forged in shared purpose.
As dawn broke, Corvaux uncovered the truth about the ivy blanketing the roof—living creatures held at bay by the enigmatic fog. We resolved to leave them undisturbed, hopeful for safe passage when our time in the ruins drew to a close.
With Rorschach scouting ahead and Deidre's Shatter spell opening the way, we ventured into a hallway draped in darkness, its walls alive with moss and lichen. At its end, a door bore an unsettling inscription in Sylvan, speaking of corrupted fruit and poisonous ichor. The cold iron key transformed the passageway, revealing the path forward.
Descending into the depths, the star's song grew clearer, its melody haunting and insistent. Two doors barred our way, each demanding a tribute. Beyond them, chambers of petrified oak and earthen pots cradling Doordnn eggs. Corvaux's move to claim the intact egg unleashed the wrath of meenlocks, arachnid horrors bent on destroying innocence. Though victorious, I did not get away entirely unharmed ( nor my pride entirely unscathed ).
But it was the final chamber that held me captive—in a sense. There, enshrined in glass, rested a staff pulsing with the star's essence. An inexplicable connection drew me in, a note of longing, and as I reached out, the room came alive with shifting hues and resonant energies. Teal light radiated from my chest, a mirror of the staff's brilliance.
In a breath, I was somewhere else entirely, bound and helpless before an ancient, malevolent presence. Though, perhaps the word ‘before’ is the wrong one, for the presence was everywhere around me, in me, like an all-seeing eye, reading me like a book. Words poured forth unbidden, populating my mind with a verse steeped in foreboding shadow. It demanded a price, a piece of my very being, my core, my soul. Lost in its thrall, I relinquished the most fundamental memories shared between my mother and I, and with it, my longing for home. Though my mother's face still flickers in my mind, her light has dimmed, a fire turned to weak embers.
I have never experienced something as profoundly upsetting as knowing I once looked to something and someone for comfort, motivation and encouragement, only to now recall purely the factual about the memories that served that purpose; to be left unfeeling about the events that once tethered me to the Earth Plane. I feel unanchored, free-floating, and yet so incredibly heavy for it.
Once returned to the chamber, shaken and violated, I recited a cryptic verse as if possessed. The words I cannot remember, and perhaps it is for the better. The glass shield promptly fell away, and riddled with fear, I claimed the staff. Its power surged through me, banishing the lingering dread and melding with my own essence.
The star's song faded, its purpose fulfilled, leaving me forever changed. A piece of myself traded for this cosmic companion in a sense, a sacrifice I pray was not in vain.
Before all else, we had best leave these cursed halls. Not only did they once belong to Eristalon, but they still do, for if that voice, that entity, was not Eristalon himself, I'll eat both my boots. Whatever else the other chambers in this vault hold, it cannot be worth exposing ourselves to that foul presence; it cannot be worth others facing the choice between death – or somehow even worse – and sacrificing a piece of one's soul.
links: Rorschach Hastaerien Blackwell Ni'Tessine, III, Esq.

character-logs/aerendyl-34.html.title: Aerendyl 34
character-logs/aerendyl-34.html.description:
Day 1 of Flamecrest, year 515 of T.A.?
With the weight of Eristalon's violating presence still heavy upon me, I pleaded with my companions to flee the vault. The others understood the unspoken horrors that drove me, so we raced back through the chambers, using our dwindling supply of tokens to unlock the doors barring our escape.
But our path was not unhindered. Oh, far from it. Luck's shout pierced the air ahead of us, drawing our attention to the green vines snaking down the walls, grasping and seeking. The staff, the star—I feared they hungered for its power. Deidre's quick thinking conjured an illusory duplicate to draw their focus, and granted me a cloak of invisibility to slip past unseen.
I ran, my heart pounding in time with my footsteps, the sonorous draconic – ’thief,’ ‘fool’ – f my ears the moment I found the top of the stairs. The cold iron key, our salvation, opened another hidden door at the end of the hallway ( as our original point of entry was now populated with those same vines ).
I don't know the path everyone took afterwards. I took a sharp left turn from the door, and then another, intent on leaving the way we came through this path clear of vines, but …
Our flight was not without consequence. Deidre, meaning to collapse a wall and impede our pursuers I suppose, or intent on opening another passage for our escape, instead revealed a sight that froze the blood in my veins. A dragon, immense vicious, its form entwined with vines and lichen, its eyes blazing with fury and searching, searching, searching—for the thief who stole its treasure, the star it coveted, no doubt.
I took comfort in knowing it couldn't see me, but I worried for how long the spell's effects would hold, and whether the dragon could ‘sense’ the star, and locate it that way—and its new wielder along with it.
Luck, ever the brave negotiator, attempted to parley with the enraged guardian of this petrified hellscape. He offered a trade while I tried to escape, allowing me to somehow sneak below and past the dragon without alerting it to my presence. To help Luck out, I even dropped my precious Moonsickle as part of the tribute being demanded. But the dragon scoffed, demanding the staff, bemoaning the silence of the once-resonant song.
The dragon's wrath was swift and merciless. It lashed out at Luck and his loyal moorbounder, Ralph, leaving them grievously wounded. Yet, through sheer determination and skill, they managed to evade the worst of the onslaught.
Now, my guilt set in long before—the moment I realised this was all because the staff had been plucked from its glass cage. My companions were all fighting and putting on their best acts to distract the creature from me, so the staff and I could get to safety. I couldn't just leave them behind, though, and given Luck's and Ralph's state at that point … I relinquished the staff to Luck, and implored him to take Ralph and flee, and find safety.
As I turned back to rejoin my companions on the roof, a figure emerged from the shadows—dark hair, red robes, a stranger whose identity remained cloaked in secrecy. Luck's hurried ( but seemingly genuine ) assurances did little to quell the unease churning in my gut, but there was no time for questions.
So there I stood, facing the wall I had yet to climb with that red-robed stranger halfway up its height, with whatever fear I felt before under Eristalon's crippling influence amplified yet again.
In that moment, though, there was gratitude, too—for Mirri's understanding, for Deidre's cleverness, for Luck's bravery and sacrifice, and Corvaux’ steadfastness. They had risked everything to protect me, to safeguard the star, even in the face of what feels like certain death. I can now only cling to the hope that, together, we might weather this storm.

character-logs/corvaux-25.html.title: Corvaux 25
character-logs/corvaux-25.html.description:
The following log is written in an old style of Elvish
Day: Unknown | Location: Feywild
Normally I wouldn't write things down, but I feel like I need to. First Thaddeus left, and now Runa. It's understandable. It's a shame that I wasn't able to ask her questions about her relationship to Yewdon before she left like I meant to. I wanted to ask if she knew anyone who went in, if maybe I knew anyone that she knew so I could give information on them. That's on me for being too slow, I suppose. I can only hope that we meet again in the future so I can ask, though I fear that her return to the Citadel, especially when she has the knowledge that I and the Blight have escaped Yewdon, is dangerous information that puts me at risk. And yet, that isn't what bothers me most. What bothers me most there is heavy scribbling over the next few lines, as Corvaux wrote down their feelings and promptly decided that it was too much
We moved on. On our way, we came across a shrine of the Raven Queen. An unexpected find, though Luck appeared to be happy about it. Hopefully he can get whatever guidance or answers he wants from those within, of which there were three. The place doesn't feel right to me, though I imagine the cause of that is the usual personal problem when it comes to places of worship.
We also met a strange individual at the shrine. Deidre, an elven individual who unsettled me with how... I'm not sure how to word it. It's certainly not familiarity, it can't be. Though she recognised my markings? And suggested that they may be connected to my "inherent stealthiness" as I am loathe to call it. I wish I had better words for whatever the fuck is wrong with me, no matter how beneficial it is. Regardless, Deidre needed help, and I am certainly not against releasing a woman who was trapped against her will.
Further on, we found a place that Luck had been directed to for an errand. But it felt wrong. It felt like home. And still I foolishly investigated the fallen tree despite my warnings. I knew it was foolish. Nothing good comes from that which reminds me of home.
Since when did the shadows become attackers in their own right? I'd better survive this. Fuck.

character-logs/corvaux-34.html.title: Corvaux 34
character-logs/corvaux-34.html.description:
The following log is written in an old style of Elvish
Day: Unknown | Location: Feywild
I want to preface this with making it known that I have never, and will never, regret following Aerendyl that day, nor any day afterwards. That includes when we went down into the ruins in search of his star. Knowing Aerendyl was able to get one of the things he wants more than makes up for anything else, and I hope that I'm able to help him even more in the future.
The Doordn egg I was able to retrieve also makes up for it. That'll either be a nice pet or a good lump of gold for us to put towards protection for Grout and Ralph against the Pale Blight.
Preface ended.
I had warned the party of the unusual vines on the roof earlier that morning. Now, as we made to leave with the star, Luck saw those same vines creeping down from our escape point. With trust that we would follow each other, we agreed to run past and escape. Mirri and I were the last ones to leave, but we eventually made it out. Unfortunately, we left only to find that the vines belonged to some kind of dragon. Did this explain Log's disappearance? Was Log now working for this dragon?
Regardless of any questions, I'm thankful that Deidre was able to keep Aeren and his star safe with invisibility from down in the tunnel. Upon seeing the state of things, and after hearing sounds of an area of the building collapsing on the opposite side to where Mirri and I was, our beautiful charlatan decided to cast some kind of illusion on herself before stepping out into the open. I have my suspicions on who it is, but gods damn are they gorgeous.
I fear that Mirri and I will have to have a very uncomfortable chat about that. If that is who I fear it is, I may very well fall victim to his charms. He's my type. Tall, beautiful hair, dazzling eyes, and he wears my favourite colour... Mirri, please tell me that isn't who I think it is.
... That aside, we have more pressing matters. (1/2)
(2/2) Deidre got severely hurt. I think the building collapsing was her attempt to deal with the dragon, but she seemed to have ended up in a worse state because of it. I was able to get onto the roof and call it Eristalon's Bitch to try and get it's attention, because hopefully grabbing it's attention means that Deidre will be able to flee to safety.
I have plans. Half-baked plans that rely on luck (not our fluffy, reliable charlatan, though I sincerely hope he is safe) and a whole lot of audacity. If I don't survive this, I am okay with that. As long as everyone else is able to escape and regroup, my death will be worth it.
And if I survive, I can brag about it.
Win/Win.

character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-18.html.title: Luck of the Draw 18
character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-18.html.description:
Feywild journal
Property of Luck
Day: No clue, I lost count and that mountain might've been a time loop.
# FREEDOM!
I have no clue how long I have been wandering the same gods forsaken parts of this forest and mountain. When I first appeared in Winter there was sun, and I tried to go through the Krumholtz Mountains in what felt like a couple months after that. Stopped counting a long time ago, but the sun isn't here anymore just the moon. I ran into a pair of fey, and I tried to pull my usual routine on them when they asked for a gift. I found a small painting of an elf, and it was the closest thing in my pack I thought worked as a gift. I don't even remember what I said, something about it belonging to a lord. The pixies said I could pass, but the pixies lied!! I was grabbed maybe a few hours later, left hanging upside down in a rope trap. They told me it was "too boring" and something about teeth??? I tried telling them I had a better gift but they would not hear my pleas and left me there.
Theres no other word for my experience except torture, I would be left in some manner of trap for sometimes days at a time. I had enough survival experience to find my own food and water, but when the trap would release almost all of the food or water would be sabotaged. Pebbles in all the mushrooms, every animal scared off, I would try and boil drinking water from the snow but if I ever looked away for even a moment it would be knocked over or have salt poured in. I've learned how to not blink for at least 10 minute intervals while the water boils despite the harsh and cold winds just so I could consistently get safe drinking water. When I would rest, the best I could expect is to wake with pine needles in my ears and nose, sometimes poison ivy or similar. Don't even get me started on the singing, even now I swear I can still hear it. After a while of this, or if I got too comfortable, I was put back into another trap so the cycle could start all over again.
But finally after only gods know how long, some travelers seeking to journey past Krumholtz Mountains appeared. I wasn't really paying attention at first, normally I am very perceptive but however long I have been in this cycle I've never spotted a single animal or other living thing besides those pixies and the plant life. I got used to not really needing to keep an ear out. When they got very close, and I finally noticed the sound of crunching snow barely a few feet from me, I jumped a little bit. I surely looked and sounded crazy, I might be just a little crazy. I mean what other kind of person has to keep an eye on their shadow?
At first I thought them some new trick, something to spice up the entertainment I was bringing the pixies. Or maybe the pixies were still angry with the threats I made and brought people to hurt me, the largest of the group certainly looked like they could. Never again am I threatening a fey I can't beat. But no, just travelers like I was who must now bring a gift so they can pass. Some fine gifts, stories, performances, these pixies had a particular interest in either teeth or disturbing events.
Had I known ages ago that is what made for a good gift to these pixies, I would've never been trapped on this mountain. Early into my banishment to Winter but after the moon replaced the sun I fought off an ogre and pulled its tooth out. I couldn't really say why I chose to do it, but I carved the word "moon" into the tooth. But, I do want to remember my hardships. In no shape or form does this punishment fit the crime and unless the coward died first, Ambassador Ushan hasn't seen the last of me. I gifted the tooth to the pixies, the quiet one was very quick to snatch it from me. Then, finally, I was free to leave this mountain.
I chose to follow those Travelers as they marched onward, they're headed to one of the other courts, following a vision in their minds of Golden Oak. While I have never left Winter, I figured I could surely at least aid them in the journey, after all I didn't learn nothing from my time in Winter. They accepted, thank the gods. We're resting in a cave now having just gotten a glimpse of the sun. I think I will stick with these people, at the very least until we've left the feywilds. I wonder how much time has actually passed? I wonder if I actually remember when in the hells I even got banished.

character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-19.html.title: Luck of the Draw 19
character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-19.html.description:
Feywild journal
Property of Luck
Day: Anywhere between 100-300 years, apparently
My senses are slowly returning to me, though I'm still in a bit of a elated state finally free of that same repeating patch of wood and mountain. My second conversation in who knows how long went not as bad as it could have. I don't think I made a bad impression of myself anyway. Better than my first with this group, I'm sure to regain my charm in time.. if said charm still applies to this day and age?
Apparently, based solely on Mirri's memory of Ambassador Ushan, it could have been as long as 300 years since my banishment to Winter. My thoughts immediately go to my family in Baheera, even in the ideal scenario of roughly a 100 years its unlikely anyone I knew is still alive. I hope the Angel's Share is doing well regardless, if they're still in business I have at least a centuries worth of donations to catch up on. I must keep moving forward however, theres still every chance I die in the Feywilds and nothing occurring in Rakāuvi matters unless I can get there alive.
Following that I had an amusing arm wrestling contest with Mirri and Aeren, I hadn't expected to win really but it was nice levity. I also learned that I have some like-minded companions in this party, improves the odds I'll try and stick with them after we make it out of the Feywilds. Mirri especially, they seemed very excited to meet a fellow charlatan. Corvaux had a connection with the demon influence in Silver Maple, in the Autumn court. So we found rapport, or I hope we did, in my mission to deal with that demonic influence. Corvaux described a "Pale Blight" that I should take extreme caution in facing, though they also said trying would be foolish so I'm having trouble telling where I stand with them.
Further interesting me in sticking with this group, apparently they're interesting enough to have people attempting to assassinate them in the dead of "night". Runa, a very large and intimidating member of this party, was attacked by some devil worshipping poacher with a paralytic poison. They had apparently fought a group of these before meeting me, a shame I wasn't there for it it would have been quite the memory. The assassin was fought off quickly, I managed the killing blow but truly Runa was more than tough enough to have done that themselves.
Runa figured that the assassin appeared in camp thanks to a magic bag they took from them earlier. There was some brief discourse between Runa and the group, the rest trying to learn more about why Runa was after these poachers in the first place. Eventually though it was settled we would see where this bag leads, try and deal with whatever or whoever's on the other side. The cave was sealed by Aeren, and a number of spells cast in preparation, that were unfortunately wasted as all of us but a now magically disguised Runa were sent directly to magic dampening cells.
Runa, through I can only assume was clever deception, got past a little girl that was in the other room and recognized who Runa was disguised as. After writing our names into a book and giving us each tokens stamped with the symbol of Asmodeus, something that I picked up must've had prior meaning to this group in addition to the devil worshippers here, we were able to walk free of our cells and explore what a disembodied voice explained to us was "Dain's Prison" and a demiplane.
As a sign off, I'm trying to steal a cold stone/gem/whatever that these people were using as a part of their cooler. Apparently it might explode if I try and chip pieces off, dying in a freezer is probably near the bottom of my desired ways to kick the bucket so I'll just stick to stealing the food if I can't get the rock.

character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-23.html.title: Luck of the Draw 23
character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-23.html.description:
Feywild journal
Property of Luck
Day: Roughly 309 years (no wonder my back aches I'm 335 years old)
Ive done some more traveling with this group, and I have only become further convinced I would like to continue traveling with this group as I work on rebuilding my reputation and legacy, not that I had much of either before. Our journey has taken us to the Scarlet City, finally beyond the Krumholtz Mountains and very near the Autumn border. To sort of catch us up on entries Ive missed, Corvaux had caught a disease of some kind interacting with a portal to the Abyss when they were still on the material, we have plans on journeying to Silver Maple and dealing with the pale blight, we went aboard the Crimson Gaze to party, fight, drink, and get our fortunes read, I ended up learning exactly how long Ive been away by talking with the crew. Beyond that, mostly shopping for silver, pale blight protection, and my brand new companion Ralph an absolutely beautiful moorbounder that doesn't like to stay still or move from my side.
The previous night, after our party on the Crimson Gaze, I had gotten my first talk with Crowley in quite some time. I haven't just yet explained Crowley to the party, I can't really think how to word that I have a red eyed crowlock visitor in my dreams that gives me information. Not without sounding a little crazy, though it's potentially nowhere near as alarming to this particular group as it would be for anyone else. Crowley in their typical slightly disjointed fashion informed me it was still very necessary to head to Silver Maple, two demon presences were still around, they also mentioned something about siblings that I assumed was not being literal and just referencing that others like myself were sent. Crowley also made it clear to bring silver, holy water, and plenty of food which we were able to find in spades while shopping in the Scarlet City. Well except the food, I may just gather or hunt it myself.
While shopping I met Josiah, a merchant within the city, who had on offer a periapt that could significantly protect Ralph from the Pale Blight. It was very expensive and after all the shopping I was all but broke, so instead I offered up ranger services and have received a list of items to collect for a discount on a future item purchase. Hopefully I can gather the gold and items to be able to afford that periapt for Ralph, his safety has quickly rose to the top of my priorities. To that end, Mirri has made a deal with me for the shards and powder of Flail Snail eggs she had, and I ventured north with Ralph and Corvaux to find some other items. We ended up discovering a cave leading to a Frost Salamander colony where using some rabbits I caught, a nearby tree, and rope, I had set up a simple snare trap to try and get some of the frost salamanders teeth without too taxing of a fight.
Im writing this section while we wait for a salamander to get stuck in the trap, will update after the fight.
Update: It immediately went wrong. First of all it was MASSIVE I knew some surface level knowledge but I certainly wasn't expecting an ice breathing lizard the size of two or three moorbounders put together. Ralph had to pull out of the fight almost immediately, I spent a considerable amount of time just trying to keep them standing and taking mostly missed shots on the salamander with my bow. Corvaux thankfully is an extremely capable fighter, they handled the fight almost single-handedly. In a moment of shock and terror Ralph went down from the salamanders frost breath but I was able to heal them with my slumbering dragon vessel. Basically the only reason we survived is because my trap managed to hold the entire time, though Corvaux might've somehow won regardless given how much damage they dealt.
In the end, we got out of it with three of the salamanders teeth, Corvaux didn't really get anything out of this fight though so I should figure out some way to repay them for the help, it wouldn't have been possible without them after all. I've also decided Ralph simply won't be aiding in future combats, I can train them as a hunting/scouting companion instead of a battle one so they never get that close to death again. Frankly I'm a bit ashamed of how little help I was on the martial front of that fight, I need to be so much stronger than I currently am. We're resting for the night in the city and I believe we're headed to Autumn next. Very excited to finally be out of Winter after so long.
Note to self: Absolutely NEVER sell that slumbering dragon vessel, Ralph would have died without it.

character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-24.html.title: Luck of the Draw 24
character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-24.html.description:
Feywild journal
Property of Luck
Day: Not just yet, almost?
Upon waking we were greeted to Mirri explaining Runa has left, leaving a note behind that they have left to the Ironwood Citadel. Some of the others were a bit disheartened at this news but truly I barely knew them, I hope I didn't come off as too cold about the situation.
We're headed into Autumn to a place called the Fallen Halls, I took the opportunity to guide the party toward "Golden Oak" the last time I stepped foot in a court besides Winter I was still a merchant traveling the roads of Sylvari so my sense of paths and other more comfortable ways of traveling were at best minimal and more likely non-existent. Despite that we did all make our way forward, finding ourselves in front of a shrine to the Raven Queen.
There was also the sound of a lute playing a strange haunting song, the source of which was someone with Elvish features named Deidre. Initially I felt that she spoke like a liar, or like someone who wanted something, I haven't met many who would offer so many compliments and not have ulterior motives. Perhaps I was getting the wrong idea from them but despite how they acted they were still asking for our help, something I wasn't going to walk away from.
