Apparently a group of masked people had somehow bound her to the area, specifically a mansion around here. Where we found her was roughly as far as she could go. When I asked why the only reason she gave was that they wanted her talents as a bard.
I asked that I get a brief moment in the shrine before leaving to help Deidre. I wasn't actually expecting others to already be inside, other worshippers for the Raven Queen. Deidre had mentioned she would visit the shrine often as well, though I don't believe she is an actual devotee. I took the opportunity to speak with one of the three tending to the shrine, ensure that I was worshipping the Raven Queen properly and to learn how I might better serve them. I even wish to move forward as one of their clerics if I can.
After that brief discussion, I was informed of a worshipper who was meant to collect offerings near a fallen but still living tree that had not returned with those items. I agreed to retrieve those items, made my own offerings of items I collected in Winter to the shrine, then headed out to find those offerings and help Deidre.
We have approached the fallen tree, and Corvaux warned us of danger, Deidre vanished with invisibility and Corvaux is approaching the tree. I stand ready with my bow sensing that this will almost certainly break out into combat.

character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-28.html.title: Luck of the Draw 28
character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-28.html.description:
Feywild journal
Property of Luck
5th entry since being able to leave Krumholtz.
The gaps in these entries are not going to improve, apologies to future me when they get really confused trying to remember what happened between meeting Deidre and leaving that manor with a myconid we met in 100ft deep hole. Though I really should get better at writing down my experiences in the Feywild.
In short and not necessarily in order, we explored the manor briefly and I personally got to enjoy sunlight for the first time in I don't know how long. The manor Deidre was bound to seems to have belonged to Eristalon, but where we needed to go to free Deidre was actually below the manor. There were several revelations related to Aeren and a journal they've been carrying around which had us certain this journal cannot ever end up in the wrong hands, not to mention an eventual reveal that a hags eye was watching Aeren. We learned Deidre doesn't have a pulse, explored the strange place under the manor which was full of various treasures, strange items, and unfortunately many many dead to the point that more than one room had the very walls packed with bones.
I'm still not quite sure how exactly we freed Deidre, when we found the room with a strange ritual circle surrounding a place someone would be chained to the floor, Mirri had us leave the room. I was wary, but there wasn't much I could do alone to press for answers. But after some time, we all met up again and Deidre said they could leave this place. Before that however Deidre wanted to lay to rest her friend Kai, which led to us entering the aforementioned 100ft hole. I feel like I should've done more in that place, I worship a death goddess and contributed little more than vague memories of elven funeral rites. I know in my heart that I can contribute more, I cannot disappoint them.
Im not sure how to explain the 'star' Aeren was able to hear while we were down there. To him it was deafening but it took some effort for me to hear and then make out words from the noise. We were going to take a boat and find the source of this noise but the boat belonged to a myconid a short distance from the vessel. They introduced themselves as Chip, and mistook me for a member of the 'Rusted Swords' I decided to go with the lie, maybe gain just that much more favor at least with Chip. I did have to explain myself to Deidre, who believed my lie and wondered if I knew her brother. I admittedly felt a bit guilty for the lie after that.
Since Chip wanted to take us to a settlement called the Blight Commune, I returned to the surface along with Aeren and Deidre. Aeren and myself collected our animal companions while Deidre packed some of her things that remained in the manor. The three of us took a surface route that would be easier on Ralph before rejoining the others.
Before we continued following Chip to the Blight Commune however, Mirri had many words for us regarding Vestan Tlanbourn and our reckless behavior. Words that I don't care to repeat here, but ones that resonated with me when they were said. I think I've slipped too far into old habits, getting cocky and reckless and fantasizing again about all the fun lies and scams I could pull. As if I learned nothing at all being sent to Winter, or getting myself stranded in the Krumholtz Mountains. I even went and managed to get myself cursed, it seems like an insignificant one right now but I don't think I could admit it to the party after everything that got said. Especially not after seeing that look Mirri had when Aeren revealed Malachai was the 'Stonecutter' aka Aerens father.
I must better myself, act out the will of the Raven Queen, be of genuine aid to my new allies, and survive to finally leave the Feywild. If I cannot improve, then I just might get myself or others killed.
P.S. With my mind able to wonder about the material plane, I started dwelling on what the years following my 'disappearance' might've been like. Did anyone miss me? Is my old home still standing? Did I get a funeral?

character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-30.html.title: Luck of the Draw 30
character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-30.html.description:
Feywild journal
Property of Luck
6th entry (post Krumholtz)
Among other events the day prior to this entry, I've discovered that the bottle I took from that manor houses a demon. More words were shared about Vestan, and the horrible things hes done, ones that should remain private to Mirri so I again refuse to share them. However at the end of it all and before we all imbibed in dream grass and druids dram I made an oath to Mirri. That in the name of my Queen, even if it takes my last breath, Vestan Tlanbourn will die.
Its not a promise I made lightly. The more I learn about this man the more I know he cannot live. I will aid in killing him not only as a service to my Queen but as thanks to the role Mirri had in freeing me from Krumholtz. Unexpectedly, my resolve in this matter has caught the attention of my Queen. Crowley said "You have chosen your first test." I hadn't been thinking of any such test when I made my promise, but it makes no difference.
I also learned from Crowley that one of my friends already had the power to solve our demon bottle problem, that they could send this demon back to the abyss a failure. Crowley made mention of a demons name, and I believe reference to one of us who could out wit it in its own language, however in the end it seemed the best solution was in Aeren finding a portal to the Abyss that already exists and throwing the bottle in before we close it.
I barely get to wake up before strange things occurred however, Mirri had exited their trance and summoned an ooze familiar. Unfortunately also summoning or catching the attention of something else. We fought some form of apparition, determined to harm Mirri, I only barely glimpsed the thing before the fight because of what appeared to be Crowley.
It was fought off quickly but not before it managed to hurt Mirri, I will keep a more vigilant eye out for this thing in the future. We learn that the demon in the bottle is from the 333rd layer of abyss, a layer that also holds Orcus. Very concerned about about my axe which was on the same table as the wretched demon bottle I revealed that I've foolishly gotten myself cursed by this axe, and had Mirri try to identify it. We didn't learn much that I hadn't already known.
We did however discuss ways to rid Aeren of that hags eye, such as feeding it to something which made me think of Xorns (potentially a Xorn could eat this axe?), there was also the option of trying to pass this eye onto Vestan or throwing it into the abyss along with the bottle. We didn't exactly come to any agreement yet on how to dispose of the eye, beyond light mention of looking for a Xorn. Instead we sent off Silos frog familiar to let him know we were ready to help him, we did promise after all.
I did discuss one more thing with Crowley, as I had concerns whether or not I've been traveling with the undead. They suggested that I find dragons tears, take the press and dried flowers then burn them. The smoke would coalesce around any such abomination. I don't suspect Deidre would have purposely undermined death, and theres every chance that the spark of life has simply taken a stranger form, but I must know for sure regardless.

character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-33.html.title: Luck of the Draw 33
character-logs/luck-of-the-draw-33.html.description:
Feywild journal
Property of Luck
7th entry
Just about everything has gone wrong. On our way out of an ancient building in a part of the forest that has completely turned to stone, having found the "star" Aeren was looking for, we were intercepted by vines that grew from the roof of this place down this far into the ruins. There was some understanding that these vines were growing from and potentially moving something much bigger but we figured we could just run past and get out of dodge fast enough.
I was the fastest initially, I got out and realized more vines creeped their way in through the smashed wall. I scrambled past them and back to our animals. I took a shot at one vine which was shockingly brittle (perhaps from the cold fog?) and would've fought more when a voice shouted in draconic "THIEF" and "FOOL". I simply holed up getting ready to bolt once the party had joined me. Instead, just as I caught sight of Deirdre, more vines started creeping in surrounding us. Deirdre shattered a number of them and the surrounding wall, briefly I hoped it would offer a quick escape but that notion was dismissed when I saw the massive strange half plant and half dragon hanging from the roof of this place.
Briefly through a stroke of luck beyond anything I've ever experienced before I managed to talk this dragon into discussing tribute, in return for, I assumed, us taking that staff. Unfortunately, the mere trinkets I had to offer were little more than offensive. My life was frankly saved thanks to Deirdre getting the dragons attention. I didn't see what they did but it certainly worked. I was able to get away on Ralphs back, the lead lined box left behind as part of my failed tribute.
From there I got a couple shots off on the dragon with my longbow, I briefly spotted grout, a once again disguised Mirri who I pray has one hell of a plan, and the invisible Aeren who after some quick conversation entrusted me with the staff so I could escape with it on Ralphs back. Even now I second guess suggesting then agreeing to running. The last I saw Deirdre they were being chased and attacked by that dragon, and I simply hadn't spotted Corvaux since running back through the smashed wall.
As I run from the scene on the back of my moorbounder I can only hope for their survival, each of them has work left unfinished, and it would be nothing short of a tragedy for their fates to be cut short here. The Raven Queen reminds us that death comes for all, yet in this moment, I pray for her grace to grant them more time, for their stories are not yet done.

character-logs/mirri-0.5.html.title: Mirri 0.5
character-logs/mirri-0.5.html.description:
20th of Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
A friend in the Guild tipped me off—someone matching Vestan Tlanbourn's description was seen near Jasmine’s Cliff with three others. My friend tailed them until they disappeared into the woods. Note to self: I owe them a drink.
I set out immediately and ran into two others on the road to the Felderwisp Farm—a cleric and a warrior. They made horrendous noise, all heavy armor and chainmail, so I slipped off on my own to get a better vantage point. My two “companions” made their way into the farm cabin, taking on the two guards, and I seized my chance to slip upstairs and corner whoever was waiting up there. I Charmed him and finally, after all of these years, got some answers: he was communing with someone named Zirel in a place called the Fallen Halls of Eristalon.
The cleric, Halek, was looking for a girl, the daughter of the farmers who lived here, whose blood coated the walls of their home. The half-orc was against me killing the cultists outright, as if they deserved any sort of mercy. Regardless, I stripped them bare and pocketed their daggers to sell later. I may not have been allowed to slit their throats, but I could, at least, humiliate them. From there, we headed to the barn, where I found a tiefling and a strange elf in a cage. I cleaved the tiefling’s mind in two with Dissonant Whispers and we managed to free the caged man, Malachai.
He knew the bastard’s name! He said he had last seen him in the Straterra University inSandfall City on the Earth Plane. Finally! A lead!
In a shrine on the property, we found the child, Nettie. The half-orc, Runa, comforted the child with the scrappy Tressym kitten she’d found in the barn. Nettie is a brave child, but gods know she shouldn’t have to be. She should never have had to endure this. No one should. She will be safe in the city, at least, and the local clerics can seal the rift to the Abyss here. It was open to the 108th layer… add that to my research list for when I next find a library.
Halek and I spoke about what I had learned from the cultist and he offered to send myself and my new… friend, Runa, to an Archive, where we might find someone who can help, someone who knows how I can get to that university. Here’s hoping, at least.
[Below are two small sketches: one of the cage that Malachi (sic) was placed in, and the other of Runa's Tressym.]

character-logs/mirri-11.html.title: Mirri 11
character-logs/mirri-11.html.description:
22nd of Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Oh, ye gods. I don’t even know where to begin.
So much has happened in a single day! I haven’t had this much excitement in one solitary day since I was banned from that little town. Runa and I arrived in the Archive that Halek spoke of and I got to work immediately. One of the workers? Sages? asked for research requests. I asked about him and tore through the information they have on him. He’s more notorious than I thought, but I didn’t really get a chance to dig into it deeper.
I met some weirdos.
Thaddeus is half-elf, blonde and pretty; a warlock like myself, though his Patron is the stuff of nightmares—Zirel, the name I heard at the farm. The Thousand-Eyed Deceiver. And he is, of course, involved. Alas that we are entwined, my verbose friend. I only hope you survive it.
Aerendyl is Genasi and he seemed to know Malachai. They have the same gemstone eyes, or one of them, at least. The other is amber with a dark sclera. He’s TALL. He also dug himself into a hole and sat there for a minute after I described Malachi, so there has to be more to that tale. I’ll pursue it later. He seems sweet, though.
Corvaux is only a little older than me, a Shadar-Kai elf and a rogue. She’s stunning and it seems we have… similar tastes in facial tattoos. I think we’ll have quite a bit of fun together. Hopefully. She was overly nervous about the Pale Blight. Wonder what that’s about?
But, gods, there really is too much to write here. I took notes for half-a-dozen pages and I still can’t condense it all down. The 108th layer of the Abyss, heading into the Feywild, the Fallen Halls of Eristalon, Cabiri & other names for the… I’m going to call this demon-shit TED.
He was looking for something called the Crown of the Faceless King about thirty years ago. That last wanted poster of him was dated to about that time.
I can’t stop thinking about it. Seeing his face again, even just on parchment. The eyes are still the same.
He looks older. I suppose I do as well.

character-logs/mirri-12.html.title: Mirri 12
character-logs/mirri-12.html.description:
Session 12 and 13
23rd of Bloomweave, (Maybe?) 515 of 3A.
Day 1 in the Feywilds
I’m in the Feywilds! The last time I thought about this place was when I was a girl, listening to stories Mama told me of the Ni’Tessine summer home in Melianmar, of visiting Eladrin and the long nights of dancing. But Melianmar is tied to the Summer Court, and I’m here in Winter.
Which means we should be careful. I’ve gone with the Sunstar alias, and my companions have all chosen one as well: Aerendyl is Kohatu, Corvaux is Varus, Thaddeus is Ted Barney, and Runa is Anur.
Corvaux had a bit of an… episode when we first arrived in Mosskarm, mistaking sulfur for the Pale Blight. Thaddeus has made quite the impression on the locals. I look forward to seeing which of us first pops our cherry, so to speak, with the Fae.
We shopped around for some supplies. I got a set of bone dice; might spend some time “fixing” them up. It might be best to keep my scams on the low for now. I’m awfully tricksy, but the Fae are better. Maybe I’ll learn something…
Below are two sketches: one of the bone dice, and one of the tiefling Pride, surrounded by butterlfies and hearts, saying: "Ooh, Teddy, gimme a kiss"

Speaking of learning something, we’ve set up in the Crimson Inn here in Mosskarm. While the genasi, half-elf, and I sat down to a game with a Pixie, Dex, Runa spoke with the innkeeper about the poachers they’re looking for. Whatever they said, it earned us a fine reward of booze. I sipped it, but some of my companions drank it down like they were dying of thirst. So much for caution.
Whatever disappointment I felt in the other two, I was deeply impressed by Thaddeus. He and I managed to convince Dex to part with some more information about Zirel and anyone associated with them.
We got the drunkards into a room to sleep it off, though both of them seem keen on fighting it off instead. Gods help Corvaux if fighting turns to… you know.
I took some time to case the inn. I know that Runa disapproves of my methods, so it’s better if I do this on my own, at least until I know the others a bit better. I found a group of Sun Elves & Eladrin. They called me “Vari”—they’re Summerlings, refugees. My group of weirdos are now conveniently refugees ourselves. I had to double-down on a lie, but I got a great deal of information. The Spring court is in turmoil, the land turned into a battlefield. I don’t know exactly what’s going on, but if there’s chaos, he’s likely hiding in it.
Good thing to know: Corvaux is quick to back up a lie. We’re in-laws for the duration of our time here—she’s the beloved sister to my dearly departed husband. I don’t know what made me say it. No, I do. I just can’t think about it now. It won’t change anything.
I thought of Paelias while in reverie. Of wiping his snotty nose when he cried after scraping up his knee, of putting him to bed while Mama and Rodan went out. I remembered… I remembered how it ended. It will never leave me.
Corvaux saw. Gods damn her back to wherever she came from. She saw. She was kind, sitting beside me and talking about it. She tried to comfort me, to tell me there is nothing to be ashamed of, gnawing on myself like an animal. She doesn’t understand. She cannot understand.
I’m the only one in my wretched bloodline to know shame. It’s the only thing that keeps me from turning out like There is a large splotch of ink here, where a pen was pressed to the point of breaking.
I am the harbinger of my own fate. I will not chew my nails.
I will not ache for this. I am the harbinger of my own fate. I will not chew my nails. I will not ache for this. I am the harbinger of my own fate. I will not chew my nails.
I will not ache for this. Not again.

character-logs/mirri-14.html.title: Mirri 14
character-logs/mirri-14.html.description:
Session 14
Hopefully still Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Day 2 in the Feywilds
We’ve left Mosskarm. I’m almost disappointed that we are leaving so soon, but the wilds beckon. And they are cold. The necklace Aerendyl gave me keeps me plenty warm—I’ve used the Shiftweave to give the impression of winter gear without actually needing it.
We traveled for a few hours, I assume, given that time works a bit strangely here. The landscape is entirely blanketed in snow… it’s beautiful, in a way I can’t quite describe, like… the antithesis of the Void. We stopped for a break & I asked Aerendyl about his homeland. I know he was present at the university in Sandfall City, so regardless of what I find here, I’d like to know more. I need to know more.
Thaddeus and I discussed our pacts & our souls. I wish I could help him, I wish I could tell him that this will get better, but I don’t know if it will. I don’t know. What is clear to me is just how… lucky I ended up. His pact and mine are so vastly different. My patron is perhaps the only true friend I have ever known and even that word, friend, is too small a word to encompass the truth of it. And the worst of it is that I cannot even begin to articulate how my pact came about because—
Ugh. I encouraged Aerendyl to do something foolish to take their eyes off of me. His attempts to… “woo” Runa were painful to witness, but they made for a fine distraction. I hope we can leave this place soon. I don’t like sticking to a story longer than a day or two.
We paused our hunt for Runa’s poachers to visit an icy shrine. Our guide fed some Redcaps with blood to keep them sated and I followed suit. I don’t have any plans on waking the dead. Thaddeus, on the other hand, gave a very impassioned speech about what he might learn of lost civilizations if he had the option to rouse the dead. He also wants an interview with a Redcap and a Revenant if he can find them.
Thaddeus is a gift wrapped in silver ribbons for someone like him.
That is what worries me the most.
We’ve found a big hole. Runa’s poachers are probably waiting at the bottom for the monster that has made its nest there. We’ve set up camp to wait for these poachers to return. I’m not sure what we’ll do with them—our taciturn half-orc companion hasn’t said much about what their goals are here… but I cannot fault them in that regard. You keep some things close to the chest for a reason.
Corvaux and I will swap out on watch. I’m first. I wish I could sleep. I want to talk to Hallow. I want the comfort of the Void.

character-logs/mirri-15.html.title: Mirri 15
character-logs/mirri-15.html.description:
? Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Day 3 in the Feywilds
We woke to one of the most beautiful things I’ve ever seen. The second moon, Lucanthus, was shining high in the sky and the snowfall was illuminated by a prismatic aurora from the moon… it was incredible. I could have stared at it for hours. I sometimes forget just how beautiful these places can be… how often have I become too focused on the hunting of him that I’ve missed the rest of the world around us? I wish I was a better artist so I could have captured it forever.
I have, however, captured the beautiful sculptures that greeted us, molded by the careful hand of Corvaux: behold, the Snow-friends! We need a name for our weird little gang…

We’ve learned that the beautiful effect of the second moon is a Wild Magic Surge. Great. My fellow warlock sprouted a pair of gossamer dragonfly wings! I tested an Eldritch Blast, but didn’t fully cast it, afraid of hitting something or someone out in the darkness.
I tried to cast Guidance as well, but it also failed. Great! I’m absolutely thrilled to be as useless as a Drow in a desert, as Calimar used to say.
Gods, stop thinking about Cal, you thrice-damned fool. Thaddeus and Sid have gone down the Hole. I don’t know how long we’ll have to wait.
Thaddeus and Sid have returned, I assume. We can hear the archaeologist’s voice, but we can’t see him. I’m assuming that his invisibility spell hasn’t worn off, yet another gift from Wild Magic. He says he tasted (???) some coagulated blood and described the layout of the Hole. We’re going in after Runa’s poachers. Runa still hasn’t given much in terms of answers, but I’m hardly one to judge in that regard.
And speaking of Runa! They cast some sort of spell and sprouted ANTLERS. We hadn’t gotten far into a long crevice before the poachers noticed us. It wasn’t a long fight, or particularly difficult—one dwarf got away, but we’ll be following shortly. Runa found 600 silver for each of us, 3,000 in total, and I’ve picked up some silver ink used with evocation spells, a decent pile of Blink Dog teeth and claws, and bark from a Dryad’s heart-tree which is the only salvageable part of this godsforsaken hole because I’VE GOT WINGS?? AND THE MAGIC FUCKED WITH MY HAIR!!

character-logs/mirri-16.html.title: Mirri 16
character-logs/mirri-16.html.description:
Session 16, part 2 of 3
Still Day 3 in the Feywilds
Just when I thought the day was going well. We landed in a fight with the poachers that Runa’s been searching for. They had the benefits of invisibility, or something like it. I managed to hear them coming, at least, though the damage I did was minimal at best. At least I got some money out of it.
Corvaux got hurt. Badly. I’d hoped some playful flirting and a gift of platinum might… I don’t know what it would have helped. I don’t know at all. I need to be useful to these people… or at the very least entertaining. I can do entertaining. I can do fun.
While we were recovering, taking shelter in the camp we raided, our dear Thaddeus revealed that he has been courting the idea of deals with devils in the hopes that it might free them from the Pact. I didn’t really get a chance to process the insanity of it before Corvaux tore him a new one and stormed off.
I managed to convince my fellow warlock to be patient. I know he’s scared, I know he’s desperate. I’ve been there and I’ve suffered for it. But something they said… something about trading something to Zirel in return for their soul. I felt Hallow’s fear and distress at the very thought of the question.
I don’t like this. I don’t like it at all. We need to get somewhere safe, back to some sort of civilization. I need to sleep, properly sleep. There are things Hallow and I need to discuss. I know he has a hand in this, somehow, and if he doesn’t… he would at least know where to start looking.
That is not a thought I should ever entertain. It’s as insane as Thaddeus wanting Asmodeus to break his pact. And it’s certainly not a thought I can voice aloud, knowing what I know now. I saw Runa crush the skull of that Drow. I’ve heard Corvaux’s verbal assault. Aerendyl seemed to sit peacefully out of the way, but that doesn’t mean he isn’t capable of the same violence as the rest of us.
I doubt that they’d enjoy my secrets. I’m loath to admit it, but it’s not just shame keeping my tongue tied. It’s fear.

character-logs/mirri-17.html.title: Mirri 17
character-logs/mirri-17.html.description:
End of Day 3 in the Feywilds
We left the hole rather suddenly. It was for the absolute best, of course, considering the harrowing details given to the group by Corvaux and Thaddeus. After a tense discussion of what our next steps are, we have decided to head to Autumn, to the Fallen Halls. To him.
To say I feel sick to my stomach at the thought of it is an understatement. It’s one thing to see his likeness sketched, to see wanted posters that show me that he has grown older, thinner. It is another thing entirely to face him again. I want nothing more than to put him in the ground. I want nothing more than to understand, at long last, why he has done any of this in the first place.
We left the hole, its ghosts, & its devils behind, hopefully. Along the path, we encountered two pixies, one in hysterics over what ended up being a simple abandoned pack. The other was quite fascinated with my hair, much to my anguish. I can’t wait for it to be back to normal, to run a proper brush through it again. Damn wild magic.
As we decided to set up camp here on the mountainside and continue on to a nearby village in the morning (?) Thaddeus said he wished to talk.
I gathered what I’d need to clean up after I commune with Hallow first. I’m used to the aftermath, but my companions are not, so it’s best to be prepared ahead of time.
Surprisingly mild swearing in Abyssal is scrawled across the page
“Screenshot 2024-02-15 at 12.18.09 PM.jpeg.png” could not be found.
you bastard idiot pointed-ear little fucker
How can one so smart as Thaddeus be so fucking stupid?!?
I’m on my third cup of tea because that godsdamned bottle we found in the pack is too expensive to waste, but—How can he even CONSIDER calling upon a devil to break his Pact? As if a deal with a devil will somehow be better?? As if Zirel will not know, will not punish such a foolish action??
Any plea for patience, for one godsdamned night to let me ASK Hallow what they know fell on increasingly deaf ears. Gods, I could strangle him with his own shawl for it. And what if he does it? If Thaddeus does call on Asmodeus or any other archdevil of the Hells, what then? What other sacrifices will be demanded to rescue an academic from yet another bad Pact?
It’s How
He started as an academic, too.

character-logs/mirri-18.html.title: Mirri 18
character-logs/mirri-18.html.description:
Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Day 4 in the Feywilds
Thaddeus has left us.
It sounds much too kind when I write it like that, but the truth of the matter is this: he chose. He chose his own survival. I will not hold that against him. No, it is the path he chose that I take issue with. Three souls in exchange for his own, three lives forever altered, ended maybe, to save his own skin. I have done some nasty things to keep myself alive and I’ve no qualms with killing… but I could not do that. I could not force another to endure what I have, save the man who put me here.
I will remember the bright-eyed academic who had the habit of reading everything aloud. I will remember the young man I knew so briefly. I will mourn that I could not save him.
But I will remember him. I will remember him, the name of his Patron, and the new pact he forged. I hope he will never have to face someone like me, young and broken and filled with hatred for a man they did not know, who destroyed their life in a single act of selfishness.
I only wish that I had not said so much. To have these people who have known me only a matter of days know what no one else ever has?
Worst of all was Corvaux telling me of a green-eyed shadow that watches over me. I know who it was she saw. I wish she had said nothing. I wish she had let me have but one moment where I did not have to remember it. One more moment between sleeping and waking where he was safe and I had not failed. Corvaux did not intend to tear the wound open, but it bleeds again all the same.
He would be about Thaddeus’ age, now.
All this melancholy has distracted me from a gift that nearly drove me to tears—genuine ones, not the false tears that fall after my dreams. Hallow has gifted me new marks on the palms of my hands. My hands, the focus of my anxiety and shame. My hands, that I have spent so many years avoiding, clenching in fists at my sides so that I would not put them near my mouth. And she has chosen them to hold the symbols of her love, her pride.
“Screenshot 2024-02-15 at 12.15.43 PM.jpeg.png” could not be found.
Oh, Thaddeus, you frightened fool. I want no one bound by Pact to know anything other than this. Even a fraction of this unwavering loyalty, of the love I have never been able to hold onto in the waking world.
It doesn’t matter now. We are in the Krumholtz Mountains, heading to the Autumn Court. To him.
I nearly forgot where we are. Of course we would encounter pixies & I remembered almost too late that we had been warned! We encountered a Tabaxi just before we realized we were under obligation to provide entertainment…
I panicked. All the stories I had told Paelias while he was growing up vanished from my head and I was left scrambling. The only story of sufficient tragedy was my own. I told them of my mother… and of my father. I edited the ending of course, for fear that my friends would latch onto it, for fear that I would lay myself bare before them again.
Our new friend, the Tabaxi, is called Luck, I believe they said. They seem a little… off and said that an Ambassador Ushan exiled them to the Feywild for some insult or another.
It… It can’t be the same Ushan I know of… that would mean…

character-logs/mirri-19.html.title: Mirri 19
character-logs/mirri-19.html.description:
Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Day 5 in the Feywilds
We found ourselves a cave to rest in and introduced ourselves properly to the Tabaxi we picked up yesterday; Luck-of-the-Draw, also known by an alias of Jerinn. A man (cat?) after my own heart—I wasn’t pleased to lose my bag of Blink Dog teeth and claws, but I am more than happy to help a like-minded entrepreneur make some quick gold!
Unfortunately, the giddiness of finding a friend keen on making mischief with me was short-lived. I was right… the Ambassador Ushan Luck spoke of was indeed the same one I know. At best, the Tabaxi has been trapped here in the Feywild for a century. At worst…. I’d say the kindest estimate would be about 300 years, going off of the dogwood story.
Lord Lysenthir is the Spring Emissary now, at any rate. So whatever insult Luck gave once, it is likely forgotten. Not that it will make up for the rest of it…
I took the last watch with Corvaux, thinking hard on how long we have been here ourselves. My journal says five days, but is that even right? How much time has passed in Sylvari? Will I return a hundred years later than when I left, having not aged a day?
I did take a moment to inform Corvaux of my intentions with some of Hallow’s newest gifts… and I was reminded again that I’m, well, me. I hope the creature that has made a mission of getting me into trouble at least admires my audacity.
At the very least, it’ll make a good story.
Runa was attacked. The godsdamned dwarf came back through the mage’s pack and attacked my friend. The little fucker was dead in under a minute. Good riddance.
I know I snapped at Runa and I shouldn’t have. I should have been kinder, I should have made sure they were okay first, asked questions later, but I just… I couldn’t stop myself. I saw the blood and my mind… I know where it went. That’s not the point. I should know better by now.
We went through the bag. There were measures in place to prevent intruders, something we should have thought of, but didn’t, and the bars of the cage were the same as the metal from those manacles. The ones that I could not break off. I know that they vanished after… after and I never did figure out where they went. Only the cost of their removal.
Aerendyl said they were made of cold iron. I don’t care what it’s called, I want to be as far away from it as possible. The very touch of it brings back memories that I don’t want to endure more than I already do.
First Runa, bleeding and hurt. Then the iron. I shouldn’t have snapped at her but all I could think of was…
Stop getting attached, Mirri, you thrice-damned, hypocritical fool. You know how it will end. They are your friends as long as you are useful to them. So be useful.
Runa freed us by adding us to a ledger for these Bloody Poachers. Their base, if that is what this place is, is open to us and what little I’ve found so far only confirms the half-orc’s words—these are “bad people.”
I know she doesn’t like me and probably never will, but Runa at least felt comfortable dumping some magical equipment onto me. I can do that. I can be useful. I can be a mage if that is what they need. Be useful.
Find out who’s singing. That’s useful.

character-logs/mirri-20.html.title: Mirri 20
character-logs/mirri-20.html.description:
End of Day 5 in the Feywilds
Our mysterious songbird was a little goblin child. While Luck and Aerendyl explored the larder to replace our rations, Corvaux and I slipped into the shadows, exploring the other rooms. I found a forge containing many magical things, including flail snail eggs and a strange metal I could not identify. It looked rusted, but it radiated heat. I decided it was best to be cautious and avoid touching it until the others could look for themselves. I packed the eggs and some of the notes into my bag. The notes were either written in a cypher or in Infernal, neither of which I could understand at that moment.
The goblin child, Jinx, was singing to a prisoner, someone by the name of Tanis. Someone that Runa knew.
I know nothing of the Orcish tongue, know nothing of what they said to each other, but I do not have to. I understand. I understand so thoroughly it makes me heartsick. We are more alike than I believed us to be, Runa and I. I understand the violence they have inflicted upon these poachers better than anyone. I know what pain they have endured in silence, their reluctance to speak of it save to ask for help in killing the people who took everything from them.
Jinx was frightened of us, all of us, and I can tell that she has been treated cruelly by the poachers who operate here. Tanis informed us that Dain's Prison is a demi-plane that belongs to a tiefling wizard called Spite. I wasted no time insisting that we leave as soon as possible. Another mage like him is the last thing we need.
On our way out, I swore I could see a face in the flames of the braziers we passed. I stole the ledger bearing our names—if what I saw was real, if our trespass was noticed, I’d rather not hand the bastard our identities to make it easier to find us.
We rested for a while, allowing Tanis some time to recover. She is a former Captain of the Wall, guarding Sylvari from the Yew Forest. To my surprise, she knew of him and said that he had been thrown out of the Ironwood Citadel several times. Though I have hunted him across all of Sylvari, it still shocks me how infamous he truly is… and it infuriates me to know how long he has gotten away with so much.
I had been trying to distract myself by making tea and caring for the little one. Jinx insisted she is not a child, she’s 16. Luck was shocked to learn my age, as if 112 is not only a decade out from standard elven adulthood & Corvaux is senior to me, is she not?
Our playful banter soon turned serious and we argued about what to do with the bag. I was in favor of laying a trap, but in the end, Corvaux placed it into their bag of holding.
We packed up camp, once again setting course for Autumn. We met the pixies again and I admit, I could not come up with another tale for the life of me. Carrying Jinx on my back reminded me of happier times, of days filled with sunshine and laughter, of Paelias begging me to do the trick with my ears. I haven’t done it in decades. I wonder if I even still can. In any case, I paid little attention to the pixies and their games. I only hope it doesn’t come back to bite me in the ass, as most things do.
The Scarlet City awaits, yet I am torn between excitement and dread. No, not dread. Homesick. Heartsick.
It is no one’s fault but his, but still… it hurts. It aches deep down inside me to know that there is no reunion like Runa and Tanis waiting for me when this is done.
Save one. And I do not plan on letting him leave alive.

character-logs/mirri-21.html.title: Mirri 21
character-logs/mirri-21.html.description:
? Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Day 6 in the Feywilds
We’ve arrived in the Scarlet City, the last city in Winter before we head into Autumn. What awe at the beauty I saw there, from the twisting branches of the massive tree at the heart of the city to the colors of fall, was soon overshadowed by the fact that the Crimson Gaze was docked here.
The Gaze! That beautiful ruby beauty! I couldn’t believe my eyes, but there she was, just as incredible as she was the last time I saw her. Oh, to think that I had been so young that first time, stuttering out my very first alias to get myself aboard. My first proper drink, my first proper kiss… Ember. That was her name. I remember her like it was yesterday. She had the most incredible eyes.
And I remember the friends I went with, the Moon Rats like myself who had heard every story, no matter how outrageous, same as me. There was Ros, Caper, and Eilonwy. Funny, to think back on them now. I wonder where they are now, how they are doing. I heard Ros and Eilonwy were married at some point, but we had moved in with Rodan by then and I was too busy caring for Paelias to slip away to attend. Not that I think either of them would want their ex-girlfriend at their wedding, all things considered.
Regardless, I did not hesitate to relay to my companions how desperately I wanted to visit the ship. I could have waxed poetic for hours. Before we went out, we stopped by the inn, Froggit About It, and there, Tanis, Luck, and Aerendyl decided they would much rather sleep than explore. Their loss! Corvaux and I made for the shops, grabbing more suitable outfits for such a grand occasion. Runa declined a change of clothes, but I could hardly care when Corvaux appeared looking like that. Gods save me, I might require a room to myself before the night is over. I haven’t… well, I cannot say I haven’t indulged since my last great heartache, but pathetic one-night-stands have never sated me. If Corvaux asks, though, the answer is a resounding yes.
I found myself tongue-tied as soon as we stepped aboard. It was overwhelming, standing on those red decks again, feeling like a giddy teen. Runa, Corvaux, and I all agreed to a fight, providing entertainment and hoping to win a bit of coin, too. I kept an eye on Jinx while we waited for our turn. I hope… I hope this place inspires in her what it did in me all those decades ago. If there is any place in any plane of existence where she might be safe from both the poachers and him, it would be here.
I must speak with the captain before the night is done. Runa’s fight starts soon. This should be a night to remember.

character-logs/mirri-22.html.title: Mirri 22
character-logs/mirri-22.html.description:
Who fucking knows, Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Day 7 in the Feywilds
Hungover. I hate everything and everyone, most notably myself.
Such a stellar start to my day, honestly. Not only am I fighting the hangover sent from the depths of the Abyss itself, but Corvaux delightedly informed all of us that they have an ATD… an abyssally transmitted disease, or phage. I thought it was a joke, at first, some ribbing about something I certainly thought about doing with her, but hadn’t actually done, but no. It was real. So, to the healers we go to ensure we haven’t all been infected with whatever nasty shit came out of the business end of some demon.
The healer examined us and gave us a run-down of what to expect. This particular phage comes from the 108th layer of the Abyss. Corvaux asked me how I knew of that layer, but I managed to avoid answering. If he’s meddling with it, tearing haphazardly into it, he’s risking more lives than I thought. I need to find out what he wants there, what is driving him and his followers to seek it out… and if they have some form of protection from it.
Speaking of protection… I pulled Captain Havoc aside last night. We spoke of Jinx and my desire to have her join the crew of the Crimson Gaze in the hope that they might be able to protect her from the poachers… and anything else that might want to harm her. She’s a brilliant child, intelligent and eager to please, and as much as it breaks my heart to leave her behind, I know it’s for the best. She will be safer when she is not with me. We meet with the captain at midday.
Oh, and by the way, Corvaux is from Yewdon. The Cursed Forest. And I thought my origins were cause for concern. Well, at least if it outs, I will be in grand company, I suppose.
What strikes me the most is how… hopeless Corvaux is about the Blight and Yewdon. She says there is no hope for her home, and while I cannot find it in myself to argue the finer points with her, knowing only an outsider’s perspective… it just… It hits close. I know that hopelessness in my own way. That loneliness. I’m tempted to call in favors that don’t even exist if it might make a difference. But I know better.
After the healers took Tanis and Jinx, the rest of us headed out to finish our shopping. We first stopped by a menagerie for Luck to purchase his moorbounder. Oh, the beasties! I could have blown every gold in my purse then and there, but I remembered my list of components for finding my Familiar and instead settled for bullying Aerendyl into adopting an ice wolf pup.
His name is Grout and he is the most adorable thing!!! Those little teeth will be man-maulers in no time! Oh, I can’t wait to see how this goes. Aeren refused to allow me to shirk responsibility, so we are co-parenting our pup. I’d be a terrible mother, but a stepmother? I think I can manage that just fine, so that’s how I’ll approach it.
We also swung by the Drunken Cantor, where we met the shopkeeper, Josiah. I purchased what I needed for my spells, as well as a sparking ring, just for fun. I also grabbed a pair of goggles, a scarf, gloves, as well as a change of clothes if we happen to run into the Pale Blight that Corvaux warned us about. I also nabbed a small trinket for Jinx… something to remember me by.
I split off from my companions and took Jinx shopping for some proper pirate attire. I didn’t want to get her hopes up too high, but I would do anything to ensure she gets a position on that ship. I cannot take her into a fight against him. I can’t… I can’t endure that again. We met with the captain, Wisp, Grace, and Confidence. They asked their questions and got answers they seemed to like… up until the moment Jinx left to explore the ship with Grace and the captain called me out for my marks.
I expected that, and half-lied my way through it. What I did not expect was to be asked if I wished to join them as well.
In another life, in my youth, I would have jumped at the opportunity. I would have given everything up then and there if it meant that kind of freedom. I have long admired and dreamed of that ruby ship, of her crew, of a life untethered. There was a time I would have said yes.
But they asked me if I wished to be free of my Pact. I did not lie in saying that it was him who did this to me, but… I could never abandon Hallow. I could never willingly leave her behind. Yes, I have my gripes with how the Pact came to be, with the fact that we were both robbed of our choice, but… I will stay with Hallow until my last breath is squeezed from my corpse and not a moment before.
It is just one more dream to be forgotten. No, passed on. Jinx will thrive here, I can tell. And who knows? Maybe I will see her again when the ship next makes port in Solantha. What a sweet reunion that might be…
Until then, I’m off to train with Confidence. I’ve long been able to use both hands for many things, including writing, so I’m eager to properly learn to wield dual swords and forget the sour taste in the back of my mouth that tells me I am losing, once again, a chance at a good life.

character-logs/mirri-23.html.title: Mirri 23
character-logs/mirri-23.html.description:
End of day 7 in the Feywilds
Jinx was accepted into the crew! Though I have not known her long, I can’t help the swell of pride that fills me. She’s going to be the carpenter’s mate and she seems eager to start her newest journey. Most importantly, she will be safe aboard the Gaze, safer than anywhere else.
Some days, you really do win. I think, with all that haunts my past and what I know awaits me at the Fallen Halls… I think I needed to remember this. Some days, you win. And everything, for a little while, at least, is okay.
Speaking of wins, I traded my flail snail egg shards and powder to Luck for a future favor. I’m not sure what favor I’ll call in, nothing grandiose, of course, but I’ll think on it for a while. A favor is a powerful thing to have in our line of work, so I’ll make it count.
Other than that, the rest of the day, for some of us, at least, was not particularly eventful. We returned to Froggit About It to rest for the evening. While their drinks seemed enticing, my head is still pounding, so I figured it was best if we actually recover before another night of partying. We chose the Giant’s Cabin room and gods, what a choice! We explored the massive accommodations, scrambling up the sides of chairs to reach the top of the table, standing beside a bed bigger than any of us could have imagined! Aerendyl went for the massive bath, intent on a swim, and I found myself climbing up the bookshelves to a swing on the bough of a bonsai tree. I felt like a girl again. This place has the kind of whimsy I was expecting from all of those stories I was told growing up of the Feywild. Not the teeth-stealing pixies.
Luck and Corvaux are heading out to go hunting. I wasn’t paying much attention to where they were going. I’m after one of those cinnamon rolls when I land this next jump from the swing to the bed.
Luck and Corvaux returned with Ralph the Moorbounder in tow after not just flirting with Death, but kissing Death with tongue. Whatever creature they decided to go after was more than a match for them. They almost killed the pet they’ve had for less than a day! Maybe a grandiose favor is exactly what I should ask for if this is how a hunting trip goes.
We’ll be turning in for the night soon. Corvaux and I are going to try and knock Aeren off the bed, first, though. I’d suggest a pillow-fight, but I think Runa might decapitate me without even trying.

character-logs/mirri-24.html.title: Mirri 24
character-logs/mirri-24.html.description:
Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Day 8 in the Feywilds
Runa left.
I did not know Runa long, but I did know her longer than I have known the others. Unlike Thaddeus’ departure, there was no argument, no disagreement… she just… left. And yet, I cannot really feel grief nor sorrow at their leaving. They were reunited with Tanix and their letter says they are returning to the Ironwood Citadel. Maybe it is as simple as “duty calls.”
Regardless, I let Aerendyl know immediately and the others when they woke. We ate the breakfast the room provided for us and packed our things to leave.
Into Autumn we go, to the Fallen Halls. The locals recoiled when we asked for directions towards the place, refusing to speak of it by name. I understand that sort of superstition… I have only written his name once within these pages. The locals also spoke of a wailing witch in the northern part of the forest and shadows in the trees.
The hike was relatively pleasant. The weather grew warmer as we left Winter behind. Though Luck seemed to stumble a bit on the trail, we eventually found our way to a temple of the Raven Queen. There was a lute being played nearby, an eerie, haunting song.
We’ve found the source of the music! Her name is Deirdre. She has elven features, but they’re more delicate, almost faerie-like. I’m assuming she’s a native of the Feywilds, perhaps. And she immediately began buttering us up, asking if we could help free her from her captors. Apparently she is tethered or trapped by a cult of some kind, wearing animal masks. It would be infinitely satisfying to put them down.
We stopped into the temple briefly for Luck. Deidre and I flirted a little because I simply cannot help myself. When was the last time a relationship with a bard fond of the color black went well for me? Never. It has never gone well for me. Don’t even think about it, Mirri.
Aeren helped me find a solid stick of rowan wood to use. I explained its purpose and what it might do to help in our future endeavors.
We left the temple and continued on our way to free Deirdre. However, along the way, Corvaux told us suddenly to stop. I’m crouched down behind a tree with Luck, wondering what’s happening
What the fUCK IS THAT WHAT THE FUCK—

character-logs/mirri-25.html.title: Mirri 25
character-logs/mirri-25.html.description:
Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
End of Day 8 in the Feywilds
Well, now that we’re done jumping at shadows, literally and figuratively, I’ve come to a conclusion. The stories I was told growing up about the Feywilds are complete bullshit. Sure, there might be some hope for the Summer Court, but all that I’ve learned since I’ve been here has done nothing but disappoint me.
Poor Corvaux took a beating, so I’ve offered my arm for the time being. As we neared the “manor” that Deidre told us about, I was surprised to see not a house, but a massive tree. It wasn’t until we got much closer that I saw the stained glass windows and carved steps. Once inside, we started to explore, poking around every crevice and destroyed room. Gods, how long has this place been in pieces? Or, more concerning, how long has Deidre been here?
As we climbed the tower, feeling the beginnings of exhaustion in my bones, we came at last to the living space and there, upon the head of a gaudy statue, was a jester’s hat fit for a king of fools. I had to have it, so once it was secured, I continued my exploration. Deidre’s Alarm Spell was set at the door, though half of it was just the word “beans” written over and over again in various tongues. None of the traps we have seen were dangerous—they were warnings only. Strange.
Corvaux and I spoke with Deidre about Eristalon, though we did not get far. Her captors were connected to Eristalon, somehow, though getting information from anyone here about it is like pulling teeth. Deidre was a pet bard, bound to this place and forced to entertain.
I wanted to rest for a while, but Corvaux called me upstairs and I am so glad that they did! There was an art gallery there, filled with cobwebs and strange items. And there was a blue dragon egg, just there for the taking. While Luck was busy breaking strange stones growing from plants, I swiped the egg, realizing it was hollow. The three books nearby described the dragons shown in the decorations all around, a blue dragon, a gold dragon, and a jade dragon. These hunters, Deidre’s captors, were part of an organization called the Furthest Branch. I’m neither druid nor paladin, but my heart still sank to read about these beautiful creatures, slain for sport and glory.
Speaking of creatures… after we free Deidre tomorrow, it might be the best chance I have to summon a friend for the fight ahead. Here’s hoping it goes well.

character-logs/mirri-26.html.title: Mirri 26
character-logs/mirri-26.html.description:
[ At the top of the page is a carefully drawn diagram of a summoning circle. The text surrounding it is in Abyssal, indicating measurements and notes. ]
For fuck’s sake, Aerendyl, SHUT UP!
Mystra’s tits, can you let me focus for ten godsdamned minutes? If you’re so concerned about preserving the feelings of someone we met yesterday, then go kiss her ass and leave me alone while I am working. Especially you, rocks-for-brains. I see you peeking at my journal as if any of this would make sense to you at all.
Finally. Now that my work is finished and I’m not being constantly interrupted in the midst of extremely careful mathematical calculations and careful wording to make Abyssal as inviting as possible, given the nature of the language, I can pay attention to whatever it was that Corvaux and Aeren thought was so bloody important.
Right. Eating my words. Aeren shared this Stonecutter's journal as Deirdre sketched out the sigils, or an approximation of them, that keep her bound to this place. Whoever this Stonecutter is, their work is fearsome to behold—interrogating demons, devils, and hags? There is even mention of Orcus. Some of this is pre-spell plague. This Stonecutter is ancient, even by my standards. Aeren confirmed it—this journal is nearly 500 years old. The contents of this journal are…
Gods, I am shaking with fear. He can never be allowed to get his hands on this. I like Aerendyl, however irritating he is at times, but if it comes to it… Over and over, this journal details one thing: souls are the purest and most concentrated power in the universe… and he has tried to take mine. He failed once.
If he knows the truth—he will not fail again.
I am trying to swallow past my own heart lodged in my throat and focus on the task at hand. To undo such an enchantment or curse requires one of two things: delicate handiwork or brute strength. Thankfully, I have the former in spades.
We’ve headed downstairs. Corvaux is working on the door that leads below, where whatever it is that holds Deidre here is located and—
What the fuck do you mean Deidre has no pulse?
Gods. There is no pulse at all. She is as cold as death. What the fuck is going on here?
I will not let Deirdre out of my sight until I know what is really going on here. My companions are so quick to trust, even Luck, who I thought would know better. We have no idea who she is, nor what waits for us below. This place belonged to Eristalon himself, if the gaudy statues are any indication. And yet, these fools I travel with are turning a blind eye. I know I am guilty of falling for whatever honeyed words drop from a pretty face, but this is too much, even for a tried-and-true fool like myself. No pulse, blamed on the “curse.” Telling us absolutely nothing about what we are facing. Someone is going to get hurt.
. Or worse. They will be absolutely powerless against the honey-sweet manipulations of someone like him. And I will be delivering fresh victims to his doorstep. I was hard on Thaddeus for this very reason, and now I see it in the rest of them. I can’t watch this happen again.
The only good thing that has come from this is that we are all now 2,000 gold richer… and Aeren was bloodied by a living suit of armor. Was it petty to chastise him like a child, as he did to me, though I am more than twice his age? Yes. Do I feel bad about it? Not in the slightest. But we will talk about that another time, when I am not watching Deidre like a hawk.
We have left the treasure room behind and come to a tomb. The smell is unbearable, though only Corvaux lost her breakfast. Two of the coffins were open, but one is empty. Much as I want to investigate closer, Deirdre has stepped into the next room and I intend to follow. Whatever she’s looking for, I need to get my hands on anyway if she has any hope of having this undone.

character-logs/mirri-27.html.title: Mirri 27
character-logs/mirri-27.html.description:
Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Mid-Day 9 in the Feywilds
I truly, genuinely, cannot believe that my companions are this stupid. It has to be an act. They have to be fucking with me in some way, shape, or form. The pages of this book have seen some truly embarrassing things done in the name of impressing someone pretty, but this is something else entirely.
Deidre’s helm sets my teeth on edge. There is something about it, something in the organic shapes, refined by magic, that hides its purpose. The longer I stand in this room the more angry I grow.
They haven’t a fucking clue. The brain and heart encapsulated in magic, the surgical tools, the prayer book—if the walls begin to ooze green slime, would they take it seriously then? How is it that Thaddeus can send poor Sid to drink vile concoctions and be told off for it, while Corvaux and Aeren can gleefully poke and prod dangerous artifacts without a care in the world?
I am here, the butt of a joke, a crown of thorns that enhances rage in my hands, and all I want to do is scream. I thought they were different. I thought better of them.
You’re the same fool you have always been, Mirri Ni’Tessine. You cannot escape that anymore than you can escape what you are.
Oh! Aerendyl has a Hag’s Eye! Great! Just fucking wonderful! Because who knows how long that has been there, what it has learned, or who it belongs to! This is the absolute perfect addition to our day! Are you fucking kidding me? Abyssal, loosely translated: get fucked, the lot of you.
We made our descent to the bowels of this manor at last. The ceremonial chamber lies before us. Most of it is in Abyssal, though some of it is in Sylvan and Aerendyl informs me that the parts I do not recognize are in Druidic. So, what the hell does it say?
Abyssal, loosely translated: This place has no words of binding or bending the will. It is a place where the body and the soul are separated, and where the heart is cut out.
The heart is cut out
I have banished the others from the chamber. This is for Deidre’s ears and hers alone. I am sick to my stomach just thinking of what this place was used for. I told her the truth, all of it. And I would not have her agony displayed for all to see. She is free, in a sense, and yet, what sort of freedom does she have?
The same that I do, I suppose. The illusion of it. You think that you can walk away, and yet there is something lodged within the black hole in your chest that tells you that you cannot.
Every time I think I have found my heart again, dug it up from the hasty grave I throw it in, every time I think that this time it will be different, it always ends the same. Even here, even now. Why do I do this to myself?
Deidre wishes to lay the remains of her friend, Kai, to rest. Lack of trust notwithstanding… I understand that. It will not make it easier. But it will give her some sense of peace. At least I hope it will. Or there is no hope for me at all.

character-logs/mirri-28.html.title: Mirri 28
character-logs/mirri-28.html.description:
Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
Near-end of Day 9 in the Feywilds
We’ve descended into the bowels of this place. Some of us preferred to jump headlong into the depths while the rest of us with more common sense climbed down carefully.
And thus began the grim task of finding Kai’s remains. Funerals and their rites are not something I am overly familiar with. Mama and I were hardly invited to the funerals of extended relatives, Rodan’s family is all still living, and… and I would rather not think of the rest.
It’s only part of why I’m so godsdamned angry with them right now. I don’t know the rites. I cannot lay them to rest if something were to happen to them.
After the bones were collected, Aerendyl described a “star song” that he could hear. He said it was near deafening, and after listening closely, I could hear it too. I couldn’t understand all of it, but I heard draconic words like “celebration” and “awaken.” I reached out to Hallow, wondering if this strange song was familiar in any way. Her confusion was palpable, but she was proud of me for finding it.
Yes, I love you too. I suppose we’re on our own, then. I need something fun after today. More than that, I need to talk with my companions, all of them. I have tried to warn them, but they don’t get it. He does not understand the concept of mercy and I do not want to watch them learn that as I did.
We stumbled across a small myconid named Chip when looking for a boat to borrow. Chip lives in a nearby village, the Blight Commune. What an unfortunate name. Luck quickly claimed membership with the Rusted Swords in an attempt to make us all look a bit better, but Deidre said that her brother, Mathias, was a member as well.
We’ve split up for now, with Aerendyl, Deidre, and Luck heading through the surface path so that they can collect their furry friends and Deidre can gather supplies to travel. Corvaux and I will stay below and take the boat with Chip.
Aerendyl’s problem with a Hag will certainly come back to bite us. Chip mentioned that the Stony Wood was where we might find such a creature to settle whatever debt our genasi friend has accrued.
I cannot stay silent any longer. They need to hear this. They have to know what he will do to them. What he has done to me.
The elf I found at the tea farm, Malachai, is the Stonecutter. The journal is his.
He’s Aeren’s father.
The eyes. Their eyes are the same. And Aeren is the same age that I was and he has the book he found and it’s happening again. It’s already begun. I can’t stop it, I can’t help him, I’ve failed again and
They cannot know. I can never tell them now.
I’m sorry. I’m so sorry. im sorry im sorry im sorry The words become an unintelligible mass of ink, nearly scratching through the paper.

character-logs/mirri-29.html.title: Mirri 29
character-logs/mirri-29.html.description:
Bloomweave, 515 of 3A.
End of Day 9 in the Feywilds
I wanted to be a wizard.
It seems like such a foolish thing to think of now. But when I was young… I wanted to be a wizard. I had not always wanted it, not like some people who wake up one morning knowing how their lives will pan out from that moment forward. But Rodan offered me an education, a chance to do more with my life than scrape and scam on the streets, than to tend to my little brother. And I wanted to be a wizard. I wanted to go to a university, to put my mind to use in ways outside of trying to figure out how to get some poor soul to hand over their hard-earned coin.
It’s funny to think of it now. I know now that it would never have worked out. But I still think about it, perhaps more than I should. What could have been. What ifs. Daydreams and pretty lies. But I think I’m on the cusp of learning something new.
They know. About Paelias. I have not spoken about him in… decades. To relive it again was… It was hard enough hearing Corvaux tell me that he hovers near me, a shade or a ghost. As if I am not haunted enough by the things I have done, the things I could never have stopped. I’m sorry. Paelias, I’m sorry. I never wanted this.
They know. Or they are close to knowing. Even Deidre knows I am keeping something close to my chest.
They cannot know. They cannot know the whole truth of it. I cannot even make my tongue form the words. I cannot own the filth of it. I can never tell them. What would they do to me, especially now that they know about Aeren, about Malachai, about—
I can’t tell them. I can’t. If he hasn’t figured it out yet, he will. And if they have not figured it out, they will. And then… and then my days are numbered.
I better make it count.

character-logs/mirri-30.html.title: Mirri 30
character-logs/mirri-30.html.description:
Flamecrest, 515 of 3A.
Day 10 in the Feywilds
It may or may not be Flamecrest, but for the sake of my final threads of sanity, I’ll say that it’s the first day. I woke before anyone else and slipped out of the window. I have one mission today and one alone; to summon a familiar for the first time. I’ve worked on the summoning circle for days, tweaking the final parts of my plan. I’ve no idea if it’ll work, but nothing ventured, nothing gained. The stables, fit for traveling caravans, are spacious enough for the circle and far enough from the inn… just in case.
It worked!!! I’ve got a wriggling, writhing little mass of inky-ooze, but it worked!!
I felt the stab of jealousy from my Patron as I sank into the memories, reaching out with the intent of calling something to me. Oh, Hallow… Can a candle ever truly replace the sun?
This little thing in my hands is a friend, true, but it is nothing in comparison to you. And I could never have them without you! Think of them as a pet, a companion to keep me company. To get into mischief with.
Speaking of mischief, the little beastie keeps talking about “the other one” coming. What other one? Magic in the Feywild is more potent… did I accidentally summon something else? In addition to this little beastie? I returned to the inn, both to show off our newest member as well as inform my other companions of my… mistake? What did I—
It wasn’t another ooze after all. It found me again. I did not think that it could follow me here but it did. Gods have mercy, but it made every inch of me hurt. It never touched me, yet it had a grip on my throat so tight I could not breathe. I relived every second of that day, of the blood on my hands, of the cold. It made my tattoos hurt. It has not done that before. It did not take us long to dispatch it, but it said that it will return for me once again. Great. Thanks. Just what I need.
My newest little friend is trying to press themself into my spine as I write. Whatever that thing is, my Abyssal creature is afraid of it.
Back to what I was doing. The demon in the bottle opens a portal to the 333rd layer, where Orcus resides. The last thing we need right now is to add another demon-shit to the mix. I also took a moment to identify the strange axe that Luck picked up. Congratulations, my feline friend, it’s the weaponized form of my ex-girlfriend—insanely jealous, poisonous, fiery, and yet no matter how hard you try to be of her, she always manages to come crawling back. And you, the fool you are, can do nothing about it because gods, is she good in be battle.
Aeren informed us of his talk with his own “benefactor.” He needs to be rid of this Hag’s eye and, to my amusement and bewilderment, he suggested inflicting the Hag onto him. It makes sense, I suppose, in a twisted sort of way.
I know it was cruel and petty but the joke was there and I could not help but make it. Lo and behold, the Hag, if it is indeed the same one Deidre knows, has red hair. Just his type! A match made in the depths of Hell, just like back then.
Well, we did promise Silo that we would offer our help and we need to get a move on. And my newest friend at last has a name: Rorschach Hastaerien Blackwell Ni'Tessine, III, Esq.
links: Rorschach Hastaerien Blackwell Ni'Tessine, III, Esq.

character-logs/mirri-31.html.title: Mirri 31
character-logs/mirri-31.html.description:
Flamecrest, 515 of 3A.
Mid-Day 10 in the Feywilds
Master Silo led us back out into the wilderness. We briefly passed back through Winter—I’d nearly forgotten how close we still are to the border. The foliage of Autumn reminds me at times of the botanical gardens back home. Soon enough, we’d traversed the mists that surrounded the lake we’d agreed to deal with.
It was bitterly cold, the water frozen over. I kept my distance, even though Corvaux, from a tree high above, reported that the ice was several inches thick. This place did not just look dead, it felt dead.
The culprit was soon found. I destroyed as much of the water and ice as I could, and at the bottom of the lake, there was a key. A key made of cold iron.
That damned metal showing itself here? Not only has it dogged my steps since arriving here, given our short trek into Dain’s Prison, but I remembered now that the cage I found Malachai in was made of the same material. As for the key itself, aside from being poisonous to any and all things in the Feywild, I learned through Identify that it opens a door that is not a door—a vault of some kind.
We debated for a time what to do with the damned thing. Even placing my hand on it, my touch as light as possible just to cast the spell was enough to make my stomach churn. The manacles, the cages… no one uses cold iron for anything good. Much as I would like to find this vault the key belongs to, something tells me I am better off hurling the damned thing into the Abyss, along with the man who is so fond of it.
Corvaux, Deidre, and I remained behind while Luck, Aeren, and Silo returned to the commune, intent on finding a box in which to stuff all our cursed objects. In the meantime, I offered to braid their hair.
A sketch follows of Corvaux and Deidre's hair; Corvaux has a simple French (Irieaborial?) braid and Deidre has a Dutch (Aetherian?) braided bun.

The lads have returned and with them came the realization that even Aeren can be horrifically affected by the cold iron. Or, rather, the jade set into it. The sooner we are rid of all our curses, the better.
Mine is not so far, now. I asked Silo to spread the word that we are trying to rid their community of the key, lest the locals view our having the key as a declaration of war. We’ve entered a beautiful forest on our forward, following the directions the mushroom man gave us. But the beautiful colors and lush forest floor soon gave way to stone… frozen in time.

character-logs/mirri-32.html.title: Mirri 32
character-logs/mirri-32.html.description:
Flamecrest, 515 of 3A.
End of Day 10 in the Feywilds
Walking through this stone forest reminds me of my rare visits to my stepfather’s workshop—there were always remnants of his projects scattered across the floor, bits of stone crunching underfoot. I learned quickly to wear shoes with thicker soles when I visited. I am very much wishing for thicker soles right about now.
Corvaux’s tracking skills are incredible and we soon found petrified faces looking back at us. Three of them wore the symbols of the “Autumn Authority”, or the lackeys of the former Archfey of Autumn. The very same who imprisoned Deidre. Her fear was palpable. It’s a fear I understand well. So Corvaux and I toppled or crumbled a few of the statues, save one we saw that was likely dead before being petrified.
We took a short break to offer some snacks to our animal (and ooze) companions, and then found yet another petrified statue. But this one was different, her armor far finer than the others. Deidre did not recognize her, though in the end, I took a sword to the statue in an act of solidarity.
And then we spoke about him. Or, rather, the fight awaiting us with him. Deidre offered a tattoo, something that might imbue me with magic of some kind, and I told her I’d think on it. It almost seems like a betrayal of some kind, to have someone aside from Hallow mark my skin. Aside from that… I gave Deidre a sheet of instructions for our friends to follow in the event of my death.
They all seem so assured that I will survive. I do not have the heart to tell them that I am okay with the fact that I might not. It would, at the very least, be a fitting end.
Our search for Aeren’s star continues. We pressed forward until we found a shattered structure. Unfortunately, we also learned that the destruction happened after the petrification, and was caused by a dragon. Because that’s just what we need.
We delved into the depths of this place, finding the greenery that Corvaux’s lost kobold had come to investigate. And we also found traces of more cold iron. We agreed to try the key here, to see if there was any “door” it might open. Which meant opening the case and fetching it.
Which required a disguise.
Luck was the only one present when I made the choice. If the hag’s eye latches onto the first face it sees, I intended for it to be his. My skin is still crawling from it, but I did it—I took his form, however briefly. Luck swore not to say a word but it’s more than that. I hope he did not look too closely, that he did not see—
It was too quick and Luck was too exhausted. He wouldn’t have seen. He couldn’t have. I will never do something so stupid again. Someone else can risk their skin to put the key back in its place.
The cold stung down to my very bones. I passed it off as soon as I could, only for us to agree that it would be better to wait until morning. Considering the threats we have faced lately, I cannot help but agree, no matter how frustrated I might be at the stupid risk I took.
I’ll spend the rest of the afternoon training and making tea. Aeren and I have second watch, and I might spend the rest of the night trying to teach Rorschach words that are a little more complex than “mouth.”
links: Rorschach Hastaerien Blackwell Ni'Tessine, III, Esq.

character-logs/mirri-33.html.title: Mirri 33
character-logs/mirri-33.html.description:
Flamecrest, 515 of 3A.
Day 11 in the Feywilds
Aeren and I had a heart to heart during our watch. He asked if he could practice his card reading with me and I agreed, only to regret it almost immediately. My Genasi friend asked me if there was more to my desire to kill the man who ruined my life.
Of course there is. I need to know why. I need to know what possible justification he could have for doing this to me, to Paelias. The truth of the matter remains that I was meant to die that night and I need to know why—
I will not get into it here. These pages have already seen my writing in those early days that followed my disownment & the grief and rage that drove me half to madness. That same grief and rage that leaves my tongue leaden in my mouth. I cannot speak of it. Especially not to Aeren.
Corvaux informed us when we woke that the ivy that gathers on the stones here is alive, more so than plants usually are. The cold iron is all that keeps it from coming any closer to us. They are Fae creatures of some kind, and I’m not particularly keen on waiting around to find out exactly what kind.
Rorschach squeezed through a tiny crack in the wall and I could see through his eyes (?) that the door that needed to be opened with a sacrifice led to a stairway. And instead of offering anything of value, we simply tore down the godsdamned wall. It felt good to swing that hammer around a bit.
We dove headfirst into the bowels of this place and found our door-that-is-not-a-door. The inscriptions here are unnerving, speaking of “ruptured, softened flesh” and awakening “the most holy of the damned.” These are the same bastards who tortured Deidre. I should not be surprised, but the words unsettle me nonetheless.
Corvaux discovered a Doordn?? Egg?? Of some kind. And of course the moment they touched it, Meenlocks rained down upon us. Only Deidre was paralyzed temporarily, but once she recovered, we moved on, reaching at last—Aeren’s star.
What happened the moment he touched the dome, I do not know for sure, but something has changed him fundamentally. It’s something in his eyes, in the strange chant that passed his lips… It’s like something has been taken from him.
Something he traded away.
links: Rorschach Hastaerien Blackwell Ni'Tessine, III, Esq.

character-logs/mirri-34.html.title: Mirri 34
character-logs/mirri-34.html.description:
Flamecrest, 515 of 3A.
Mid-Day 11 in the Feywilds
Aeren claims that he met the former master of this place, Eristalon himself, when he picked up that staff. I signed the name to confirm, not wishing to speak it aloud, both in front of Deidre and here, in a place that has his influence etched into every wall.
It seems the former archfey is maybe not as “former” as we believed. His power lingers, that much is clear, and we agreed to make our exit as quickly as possible, only to find the vines that Corvaux warned us about had followed us below. Aerendyl, Luck, and Deidre managed to flee first. At the top of the stairs, I heard angry Draconic, demands for tribute, accusations of thievery.
Oh we’re fucked. We’re so fucked it’s not even funny. I swore I’d never do it again, but I took his form. There’s no one else I can think of that would have the audacity to do what I’m thinking of doing. Gods save me. I can’t believe I’m doing this.
Come on, you bastard. Let this be the only good you have ever done me.

character-logs/runa-15.html.title: Runa 15
character-logs/runa-15.html.description:
session 15 day 23 of bloomweave, year 515 of 3a.
any spelling mistakes are in character ❤️
we set up camp by the big hoe. managed to get some rest at last. thought of that rhemoraz monster kept hauntin me, but ef that thing was a poacher's prize, wouldn't be the strangest thing i heard. woke up to cold snow, but the borrealis took some sting off it. pretty to look at, especially with those two moons hanging in the sky. folk always talkin' 'bout how the big moon changes them lycanthropes, but most can't make heads or tails of that smaller moon, lucanthis. all I know is, sometimes it feels like it gives a body a bit extra somethin'.
dunno why corvo thought makin snow people of all us was a good idea. tadeus seem to like messin with magic too, threw some invisibility nonsense on sid, and that made the fool sprout wings. miri tried her own trick on corvo, but seemed to fizzle out.
